content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Little Inferno is one strange beast of a game. Upon startup, the game immediately presents nothing but a fireplace, and tasks players with simply burning the few letters they have with them. Immediately afterward, a catalog is sent, and the rest of the game is spent purchasing items and setting them aflame, watching the strange animations each item has. My first reaction, upon realizing what the game had in store for me, was "They made a whole game out of this?"The humorous thing about this game, though, is that it WANTS you to feel that way. In fact, it encourages it by making you wait long, painful periods of time - upwards of a couple minutes - for your new kindling to arrive. And yet, for whatever reason, I found myself enjoying the experience. It was strangely appealing, setting things ablaze, and I wanted to see what would come of my neighbor, who continuously sent me letters. So I kept playing for 3 hours straight.In the end, the game throws a massive twist on you. I don't want to spoil too much, but let's just say that I was completely thrown for a loop and felt like quite a fool for having spent such a long time playing the game. This isn't a criticism to Little Inferno; rather, this is the highest praise the game could achieve, because it is exactly what the developers sought to accomplish.A couple of days after playing Little Inferno, I can't help but reflect on it fondly and reminisce. A remarkable work of satire, I truly believe this game will be remembered for all time as one of the most humorously self-aware experiences this medium has ever created. Well done, Tomorrow Corp.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												I beat this game in 3 hours. It's an amazing game. When I bought it with the Humble Bundle, I expected it to be this lame indie game about burning stuff. Imagine my surprise when I realized that I beat the game in one session 3 hours later. The visuals are amazing. The cracking sound of burning embers is so relaxing. It was so relaxing just watching the fire and hearing the flames spread.Furthermore, the story is captivating. I excitedly opened each envelope and laughed and cried along with the characters. The  ending was amazing. I really felt the characters.My only complaint is that it gets a bit repetitive towards the end. By then, I caught myself buying random stuff and burning them immediately, haha. However, the combos prevented this, and it was extremely fun trying out different things.Visuals: 10/10 - Amazing dynamic flamesSound: 9/10 - Amazing sound of burning embersStory: 10/10 - Captivating storyGameplay: 8/10 - Fun, but a bit repetitive. I'm not sure if the replay value is good.-------------------Overall: 9/10I heartily and warmly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												It's very polished, the music is incredible, and it looks lovely. The item descriptions are full of snide and sometimes sinister remarks. The general atmosphere of the game is a blend of frenetic happiness with dark undertones, and it conveys that really well.Otherwise... I mean I get that it's satirising consumer culture, mobile games with micro-transactions, and entertainment addiction... But in the end all you're doing is burning things, collecting coins, and burning more things. You're doing the things you're supposed to be laughing at.As for the story being told, it never really resolves into anything that makes much sense; instead it's happy to drop hints here and there and pull at your heartstrings without substance.What little gameplay is there is pretty refined - the burning effects and physics are fun to toy with.I think "toy" is more fitting for this than "game."Overall, I still recommend it because it's so well put together. And really, I want that soundtrack.

number of helpful: 81 of 100 people (81%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Fireplace simulator 2013 is more than just a sandbox game. The base storyline is in a world full of what seem to be orphans, the planet is getting colder, and to keep warm the “Tomorrow Corporation” (Also the name of the developers) make an entertainment fireplace for all the boys and girls. The story continues as you play more into the game.The base gameplay is clicking to create fire, and buying this from a catalogue to burn them. Unfortunately, you have to wait real time in order for the toys or electronics or whatever to arrive. This mechanic in the game is a massive downside, because some items in the later catalogues take a full 2 minutes. I see that the Dev’s wanted to make the game last longer but it's an annoying amount of time. Not long enough to alt tab and do something else, but long enough for the player to be annoyed. This time can be finished but using stamps, which can be collected by burning certain combos of objects. The list and what items required are online so this can be figured out easily. The gold coins you use to buy the objects to burn, are earned by, you guessed it, burning things. Its almost impossible to go broke in this game, with profiting from burning most things, and random spiders coming down and providing $ from their burnt corpses. Burning combos, at first, seem to be the only objective. After a little bit of time someone in the next room sends you a letter, befriending you. Her and “The weatherman” start to produce a legitimate storyline, making the game more appealing, drawing the player to play more. After grinding out the combos the player is handed a combo that is very easy to do, implying said player has a good memory. After that combo is completed a whole new world and story is added to the mix. The story is added in gradually but soon becomes the full focus. Its not only a well told story, but it's also a grasping one. The graphics of the game fit the game alright, but the music in-game make the world around you feel so much darker and lonely, suiting the game perfectly. Little inferno does some things right. The sound and music is amazingThe story is one of the best i have ever seen out of an indie gameThe combos, are witty and require some thinking, making it more immersiveThe fireplace looks good, and get to annoying to look atThe objects you burn are rather comical The ability to toss burning objects around your fireplace is good fun.Little inferno does some things wrong too. The lack of achievements and playing cards make the game a time killer, lowering their audience The story although great, is slow to get started. The repetitive nature could leave some players bored after an hour or twoThe combos are both hard and easy at the same time, depending on the player’s skillThe combos are really easy to look up shortening the game time and lowering the funLittle inferno, although a compelling story and a good time killer, isn't really worth the $10.99(CAD). With the lack of achievements and playing cards, it seems almost like a narrative interactive book, then a game. The price aside, i think people who love a great story, or even just wanting a few hours to go buy, should pick up this game. If it's ever on sale, get it. This is the weatherman, signing off. We’re all going to be okay.

number of helpful: 59 of 67 people (88%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												This game has literally no right to be good. But it is! It is incredible. I have now finished it about 5 times on different platforms. This playthrough I sat through and completed the entire game in one single sitting which took me about 3 and a half hours. Honestly one of my favourite games ever made.So what is the premise of little inferno? Well you burn stuff. It's that simple. Burn everything you get given then buy more stuff to burn. So that sounds boring?! The real fun comes from making combos. Burning the right items together gives you a combo. You get a hint for each of these combos and then you have to work it out yourself. What really builds this game though is the story. There a few different characters that build together a story throughout the game. They communicate to you only through 1 way, letters. Except somehow the developers seem to find a way to make you relate to these characters and gets them to convey a very wide range of emotion. The story is unique and really keeps you attached throughout the game.The style of the game is incredible. What I mean by this is the graphics and the soundtrack. They both fit together perfectly. The graphics are cartoon like and everything is stylized incredibly well to fit the theme. The soundtrack is a mixture of tracks that are upbeat and slow and always convey the emotion of the scene. The main theme is great and they even have a nice little sing a long video at the start with a catchy but scary song (you'll know what I mean when you see it). It is definitely something I would be willing to listen to outside of the game. So theres not really much more I can say about little inferno. The concept of the game is simple and sounds boring and terrible. But somehow it is incredibly fun. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone! TheIronicGamers rating system Don't ever buy this game. Maybe consider it on a sale. An average game.A good game that should definitely be considered.A must play!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Somewhere uncomfortably wedged in between hilarious and deeply disturbing is this game.What will you do the first time you light a bus full of school children on fire, hearing their screams before it explodes?Will you laugh?Will it shock you?Will it scare you?Or will you glare mindlessly into the warm orange abyss, and feel nothing at all?Is this game about the dangers of over-consumption and runaway-consumerism, leading to a post-apocalyptic society where children are asked to burn their toys in a desperate attempt to stay warm to survive?Is this game about corporate and government wrongdoing, having milked an entire society dry of all it's resources until the CEOs and top officials flee the planet, leaving the glazed-eyed slack-jawed starving populace to their fate of an eternal nuclear winter?Is this game a metaphor for the player's wasted life? Like your character who burns all of his toys in the fireplace, is the player burning his life away playing video games, staring into the warm glow of his computer monitor while the real world behind him goes unnoticed, unlived?Is there any escape offered by burning down your house, the prison that keeps you inside, or is it even worse out there in the unknown?Playing this game won't give you any answers, but it will let you ask the question.

number of helpful: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												If Little Inferno was content to be merely a game about sticking a variety of different objects into a fireplace and watching them burn until reduced to ash, it would still be recommendable, as it's full of fun and inventive items to play with. However, the game goes beyond it's surface premise, offering up a critique of its very own genre and a potentially thought provoking story set in an often unsettling and sometimes outright scary world.As the world gets colder and colder, The Tomorrow Corporation releases the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, which you are a brand new owner of. In order to combat the frigid temperatures outside, you'll spend your days throwing everything from credit cards to televisions to robots (and much, much weirder things) into your fireplace. As you burn, unlocking new items from the 7 different catalogs, you'll interact with others through letters where most of the story is told.While there are a large amount of items to unlock, and subsequently turn to ash, as well as “Combo” puzzles to solve, most of the focus of Little Inferno is on the setting and story. A story that, whether by authorial intent or not, is often vague and never very upfront with its intentions. This implicit style of storytelling allows the player to glean however much or little from the game as they want. Is the game really just about burning cool stuff? Or is it using an environmental message as a vessel to tell a deeper metaphorical tale? It's really up to you and how far you want dig into the game.If that idea turns you off, and $10 seems too steep a price to satiate your inner pyromaniac, this may not be the game for you. For everyone else, whether for its impressive fire effects, its haunting soundtrack, or its intriguing story, Little Inferno is a game likely to stick with you well after you finish it.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Little Inferno is a charming one.If you had any previous experience with World of Goo, you should know exactly what to expect out of this little piece's flavor and aesthetics. For many small games, there is a point where, for the sake of keeping up with the challenges the gameplay introduces, the player's mind effectively strips away the colorful facade of it, revealing the core mechanics to be yet another twist on an ages old arcade, which it is perceived as from there on. Here, that's hardly the case.Then again, the complexity of Little Inferno's gameplay is somewhere between that of Clicker Heroes and a bubble wrap simulator. Yet, given how deeply satisfying the look and feel of this trivial process proves, and how the occasional story shards keep popping up at just the right moments, this simplicity manages to give birth to some mesmerizing immersion.The visuals are freakishly grotesque and disarmingly adorable at the same time, and the beautiful soundtrack contributes overwhelming emotionality to the process. Invest in it just a bit, click away the build-up, and you find yourself at the story's climax, gasping for every little final detail like a revelation.Little Inferno is a cozy place to be. The flames will consume you whole. But that's okay.

number of helpful: 26 of 39 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												From one of the makers of World of Goo comes Little Inferno, a game about setting toys on fire just to watch them burn. As a new recipient of the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, along with Tomorrow Corporation’s plethora of catalogs, it’s up to you to stoke the flames. Whether it’s a pile of blocks or a gaming tablet, a fluffy bunny or a toy school bus, the final destination for all of your things is directly into the fireplace. It is there that they will burn, explode, freeze and rain. And when you’re all out of things to burn, with the fire slowly reducing your material possessions to ash, you buy some more toys to fuel the fire.Almost the entire game is spent sitting in front of the fireplace. There are no alternate fireplaces. There are no fireplace expansions. There is no clear objective as to what burning all of your toys is meant to accomplish, aside from staying warm and passing the time. The only actions you have available to you are to upgrade the amount of things you can possess at one time, speed up the delivery of the things you order and unlock new catalogs, each featuring a new set of toys to burn. And, of course, the ability to throw these toys into the fireplace and set them on fire.But perhaps I’m getting ahead of myself. This is merely a simple game about throwing things into a fireplace. No need to rush ahead of that. Like how Hydrophobia depicted realistic water collision, Little Inferno approaches its subject with much more consideration than you might expect. The fire, as it spreads from toy to toy, feels real. No two items necessarily burn the same. Toss bricks into the fire and they catch slowly, burn slowly. Toss some of the mail you’ve received and they’ll burn up quick, reduced to cinders in mere seconds.This doesn’t take into account the various special items you can burn. Everything from mini-nukes to school buses to replica moons, complete with their own gravity fields, are available to you. There’s a fan that will blow out the fire. There’s a fan that will suck in the fire. Toss one on the left side of the fireplace, the other on the right side of the fireplace and you’ve got yourself a funnel of flame, coursing over everything in between. Not happy with how everything turned out? Accidentally froze your fire over? Drop in a mini-nuke and scour it clean with a single blast.You won’t have all of these toys available to you at once. In order to access the catalogs you have to do two things. First, you must use all of the toys available to you in the current catalog. It’s a little forced, but I can see why that’s a requirement. It’s in this manner that you’ll know what happens with every toy when they burn. Secondly, you must achieve a certain amount of combos.A combo in the case of Little Inferno is when you burn two or three like items based on a list of clues. The clues, and the solutions, are relatively simple. The only trick is digging through your growing library of toys to discover which toys are more applicable. Such as, one clue might call for a Sorority Party. Throw in the Low Self-Esteem Action Doll with the Balloons and you’re one step closer to unlocking the next catalog.When you purchase an item from the catalog, it doesn’t immediately appear in your inventory. It takes time. The post office doesn’t react instantaneously, even in this world. Things may take anywhere from 20 seconds to several minutes to arrive at your doorstep. Don’t want to wait? Stamps are available to rush delivery, but they are not infinite. There will be times when the only way to proceed is waiting, sitting in front of the fireplace.Somehow through all of this there is a story. There is a lengthy epilogue that provides a surprisingly satisfactory conclusion to the game. It’s the kind of ending that encourages you to look back at the few hours you spent in front of the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace. It’s a strange sort of irony that asks you to question the lack of meaning in something meaningless, but give it time. Think about it some more and you might see how far the metaphor stretches.And then, when you’re all done, what’s there left to do? There’s not much of a reason to play it after you’ve beaten it. Once you’ve set fire to all of the things, all that’s left is to fill out the checklist of combos. And once that’s done, there’s just the never changing fireplace and your catalogs of toys. They may burn brightly, explode in variable screams, changing the colors of the flames into something truly radiant. Then the flames die out, and there’s nothing left to do but buy more toys and set them on fire again. And again. And again.Recommended

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This game is two things:- A fun casual game where you save up money to burn things by, well, burning things. Gameplay is simple, but the results are a lot of fun as each object you burn has a different reaction. You can also find specific combos (hinted at cryptically) that give you extra coins and speed-up tokens, lending the game a puzzle-element.- An unsettling setting and theme, accompanied by an absolutely amazing score and an ending that had me thinking for several days. This is not something I expected when starting this game, and it took me by surprise, and a delightful one indeed.I would recommend this game to anybody except perhaps for people that are looking for a challenging experience. Little Inferno offers a wide range of emotions, some not seen nearly enough in videogames, and you owe it to yourself to give it a try.(...maybe not at full price, but that's a decision I'll leave to you)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												At first glance, Little Inferno seems like a shallow if marginally fun game, but as you progress through the story via the catalogues, the game really opens up. It doesn't have some big epic story, nor does it have one that's consistently at the forefront of the game, in truth much of game relies on abstraction, but that's where the beauty of it lies. The game thrives on abstraction. The makes several observations that apply very much to both real life events in general, and to gamers and video games in specific. It takes the typical dysoptian/crapsack world and uses it to portray a meaningful message.The gameplay and graphics are rather utalitarian if charming, it's the story in which the this gem of a game shines, and it's one everyone should hunker down and spend a couple hours on.

Posted: October 23, 2016
												Wow, where do I start!?I'm writing this review on 10/23/2016. A friend of mine giftend me this almost a year ago,I loved it then and I love it just as much now. I think I may love it even MORE now than I did, now that I"ve had tine to sit on it.There are two very important things that I pay attention to when I try games. The art and the music; because I'm a very emotional person and I find that those are the two aspects that really get me into a game. Little Inferno BLOWS it ALL out of the water.  The art is just phenominal. It's smooth, unique, and makes me feel very comfortable. I'm not sure how that will relate to anyone else, but everything just feels so smooth. Each item has its own personality. The game controls and mechanics are very comfortable, very natural. You left click to drag and drop. Very simple. The graphics are unique and the goals are challenging as hell! You really, REALLY have to think very hard when it comes to some of the goals within the game. The music is SO very emotional... I think the music is a good 70% of the game. The dialogue is 20% and the rest is the gameplay itself. I've downloaded the music for my own personal collection because I love it so much. It is definitely someting that helped drive me through the game. The game is simple, try to match up the combos. But pay attention to the story line that SHE gave you. LIsten to her very carefully, it's very important. Listen.... pay attention! ..... what did we talk about???

content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Little Inferno is a novelty.  It's a fantastic fire simulation wrapped around some quirky humor and a thin veil of a story, but not much else.You buy things from a catalog, burn them in your fireplace, and they spit out more money than you spent on the items.  The items have a shipping time which increases over the course of the game, up to about 5 minutes at the end.  You can speed up shipping with stamps which you mostly obtain by burning specific item combos together.It's a short game, but the novelty wears off even faster.  I really hope these guys go back to a more substantial game like World of Goo again.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Admit it: you like to burn things.  No no, don't deny it, we can all tell it's true.  Fortunately, Little Inferno has your pyromaniac needs covered.The concept is simple: order things from a catalog with money.  Put those things in a fireplace.  Burn those things.  The act of burning those things earns you more money than you paid for them.  Repeat.  No time limits, no points system, no one telling you OMG DO THIS NOW.  Burn, burn, and burn some more.That's not to say there's nothing else to the game.  There's combos to create to unlock achievements, along with stamps that help your ordered items arrive faster. Money also lets you purchase access to more items, as well as expand the number of items you can hold at once.  And believe it or not, there IS a plot, given mostly through letters you receive in the mail, along with an epilogue that is a surprising gameplay shift, but still fits in just fine.You don't have to do any of that though: you're welcome to just burn things without purpose for as long as you like. Doing so is surprisingly entertaining, and really, there are worse reasons to play a game.

content:
Posted: February 28
												You burn things. I like burning things.Okay so there's more to it than that. With a weird style and sort of underlying childish creepiness (I get a Tim Burton vibe), a story starts to develop during all the mindless staring and burning. But I'd almost be happy just to keep burning things. They burn so nice. It kept me hooked and interested enough to keep going, not at all expecting the big surprise at the end. Like, woah. That was not at all how I was expecting this deceptively simple game to end. You need to see for yourself. There's a pretty heavy metaphor for gaming under it all. But I wouldn't call it pretentious. Unlike other games that talk down to you for gaming while you play the game, it's more just poking a bit of fun at the medium. Disregarding that, even if you don't pay attention to what it all means, it's still a fun game about putting things in a fire until they crumble into ash. Or explode. I'm not sure what more you could possibly need.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												So much cute! LET'S BURN IT ALL!!!This game is adorable. You buy cute little things from the store, stick them in your Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, light them on fire, and enjoy the show. Then you buy more stuff and burn that too. Repeat.Have you ever sat in front of the fire and just watched the flames flicker or the embers glow? I found myself becoming very relaxed while playing this game, just enjoying the peace that comes from gazing silently into a warm, crackling fire. It's so calm and relaxing... until...BLAM!! EXPLOSION! Well, what did you think was going to happen when you put batteries into your fire? Now you hearing screaming, you say? You didn't, perchance, just burn a school bus, hmm?There is a cute, endearing little story attached to this game. After you finish playing the "end-game," you can return to your fireplace and go back to burning stuff again. Because burning stuff is awesome.Burning specific items together can produce more interesting results. Much fun is to be had burning sets of items, looking for the right combinations. And even if you don't discover a new combo, hey, you still got to have fun burning stuff!!Burning things always gives you in-game currency (as does squishing spiders), so you literally never run out of money. This is good because it means you can keep on buying more things to burn!You can even import your own photos to burn in-game. It doesn't get much better than that.Did I mention that this game lets you burn stuff?

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												As user Puggsoy put, "Little Inferno is not a game of skill. It's a game of discovery." That is exactly what the game is. I've read that some people were disappointed, claiming that the game felt like it was missing something or lacking, but it's all in the eye of the beholder. I was perfectly pleased and fell in love with it. There's not a lot of challenge to it, if any, but there is a lot of beauty and discovery and fun for the curious who like to experiment. This is not a game for the people who crave constant action or stimulation. If anything, Little Inferno will soothe and calm you. There's something very relaxing about watching the objects burn, and the atmosphere has a very ambient feel despite wondering about the sinister intentions behind your Little Inferno Fireplace that was given to you by a big company, Tomorrow Corporation, that you know very little about. But the premise is that the world around you is freezing, and you have to keep burning things to stay warm and farther more, although it's unspoken, most likely to stay alive.This game is often described as a "Fireplace simulator," but there's a little more to it than that. It has a plot with a few surprises with a twist that left me surprised and emotional. On top of that, watching things burn never grow tiring. In fact, they often burn with pizzazz. There are a lot of unexpected outcomes, from sounds, to special effects, to beautifully colored flames. You'll be excited to burn the next thing to see how it reacts.

Just like World of Goo, the developers have taken amazingly addictive gameplay in which you throw toys and expired food into a fireplace and burn them to get money and stamps to order more; and threaded an intriguing story into it, almost imperceptibly. content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												Little Inferno is a very unique Indie game created by Tomorrow Corperation. The nonsensical, comical game style makes the game highly enjoyable and addictive. The objective of the game is to burn various items in your fireplace in return for coins, with which you buy more items to burn! When you burn certain items together you will unlock combos, these give you extra coins and when you get ebough you are able to purchase a new catalogue containing new items to burn!When put like that the game does not sound very enjoyable, however the way in which the items react just makes you want to see more of the game.Tomorrow Corp also add in another couple of characters who you get to meet and develope relationships with as the game progresses including an annoying but lovable neighbour who circums to a tregedy later on in the game.The game play is very responsive and you do not need a good computer to run the game. The colourful design gives the game a very positive atmosphere, which seems to be uncommon in newer games.The only down critisism that I have for this game is that it does not take a long time to complete, if you do not focus on unlocking all of the combos you could complete the game in little over 2 hours. But, if you wish to piece together all of the clues than you would have to spend a lot more time on the game.To conclude:Little Inferno if a brilliant and unique game, it includes a lot of fun puzzles to solve and will keep someone entertained for a number of hours. It's relaxed game style means you are able to play it without having to stay and "finish this bit" as it saves the game as you go.Graphics: 8/10 Fun but still detailed and high qualityFun: 9/10  You can spend alot of time on this simple game and not get boredOveral: 6.5/10 Superb game but it is a little short for my liking.I would recommend this game to all people, exept children who are easily distressed/upset.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2013
												To paraphrase Hyperbole and a Half: "Burn ALL the things!"Little Inferno is a curious way to waste a few hours. You have a fireplace. You order toys and other objects from catalogs not to play with, but to burn. Sometimes, the mailman brings letters from the neighbors. You'll burn those, too.It's a little bit creepy and, yes, entertaining. Is there more to this game? Yes. No. Both, I think.Fans of Kyle Gabler's earlier work, "World of Goo", will recognize a similar smug poke at the things we take for granted in this always-online age, but I don't mean to suggest that there is somehow more of a game here than "burning stuff." Suffice to say that there are varying levels of interaction going on with the things you burn. I don't think that's a spoiler. It's game enough that there is a beginning, a middle, and an end.However, the artistic style and soundtrack are the true star of this game. My daughter walked in on me playing, and within 10 seconds she asked "Is that a new game from World of Goo?" Gabler's artwork and music are immediately recognizable. Just as in "World of Goo", the art of Little Inferno defines a warm and unsettling world, where a fun game with simple mechanics is just the exposed surface of a much larger world gone awry. Or... not! These games can be played by a 5-year-old, but jaded adults will naturally seek deeper meaning.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												It's a physics sandbox. Throw stuff into a fireplace and watch it burn, or smash it against the walls to break it. Burned stuff drops money you can use to buy more stuff from the catalogues. Try burning all the objects and watch each one burn in a unique way.But wait... isn't there something a bit more sinister going on here? What's up with the pointless combo system? Why are the timers on deliveries so long, making it so that you’re spending most of the time just staring at an empty fireplace? Why do so many of the inanimate objects you purchase seem alive? And what’s even the point of the money, if the fireplace will just give it right back to you after you spend it?Little Inferno is a game with a message. I could spell it out for you, but in 2-3 hours the game expresses the message much better than I ever could. Just play it, and find out for yourself if there's something in this world that's more dangerous than fire.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												There's a lot more to Little Inferno than meets the eye, but let's start with the basics. Do you like to burn things? If, like me, your answer is YES!, then the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace is for you! Additionally, if the idea of squashing and/or burning spiders appeals, then this product is also for you. If neither of these hold long term appeal, never fear - you can collect coins and purchase products (to burn and begin the process again). Everyone enjoys purchasing digital junk! Not you? Well, what about progressing through catalgoues and collecting GOLD STARS? And COMBOS. What about combos? Everyone likes combos!It's this commentary that makes Little Inferno great - it has something to say about the state of games, about itself, about you. Yes, it is a ridiculous game, but you'll get more than you bargained for from it - or at least you should.So, how does Little Inferno actually play? Well, it's best described in three easy steps:Step 1: Burn items.Step 2: Collect coins.Step 3: Purchase items.Rinse and repeat. But I'm not a pyromaniac. What's the point?The point is to burn your way through catalogues of items to unlock new catalogues of items to burn. If you're a completionist, you can get gold stars on all of your catalogues. If this (understandably) isn't enough, there's combos - these are likely what you'll spend most of your play time on. These are Little Inferno's puzzle aspect. From the title of the combo, you have to work out which items to burn together to achieve the combo. This gets a bit trickier towards the end when you have multiple catalogues of items to choose from. That's about it for Little Inferno's gameplay. As for the /point/, well, you'll have to find that out for yourself.But, as much as there is more to this game...10/10 - would spend a day burning fake items in a fake fireplace again

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Background: Picked up in a bundle, played with my 8 year old nephew.Impressions: Enchanting. Absolutely charming and lovingly crafted. I've had few gaming experiences quite as rewarding and intriguing. The simple, talkative exposition via letters is pitch perfect and the holds together perfectly with the gentle score and cute visuals. The story does take some oddly dark turns and some of the visuals are mildly creepy (not for young kids, without being anything bad.. just not all sweetness) which I actually enjoyed as it made the plot all the more interesting.I can see this is not a game for everyone. It's short, simple and lots of text to read. But if you take the time to enjoy it it's a fine experience.The Good:*Simple mechanics, fire looks and works great*Charming visuals, music and characters*Each item burns differently.*Builds a world though letters and descriptive writing*Dark plot twists and creepy toys add interest*Combo system is rewarding to puzzle out*Superb, rewarding and unexpected finaleThe Bad:*Could be longer, all over in a 4-6 hours*Some combos are really hard to figure out*The darker elements of the toys and story can be off-puttingRecommended for: anyone with a love of simple, elegant puzzle games with beautifully crafted stories.Conclusion.8/10. Not for everyone but there's a lot here if you give it time.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Little Inferno is a toybox game. There aren't any set objectives, there aren't any rules, just pick up your toys, throw them into the fire, and burn them. Ultimately that is the premise to the entire game however there is more to it than that.You begin with a small number of toys available to order from a catalog, and you can unlock more toys in that catalog by earning money, and you earn money by burning toys. The more toys you burn, the more you can buy, and so on and so forth. You can only 'hold' so many toys in your inventory at one time, however you can increase the size of your inventory by spending some of your money which makes the game a little easier as you progress.There are numerous other toy catalogs that you can unlock playing the game, but to do so you also have to work out combinations of toys to burn together from combo names which are given to you. Making combinations of burning toys will not only unlock catalogs it will also give you stamps, and these stamps can be used to reduce the time it takes for your toys to arrive once you have ordered them from the catalog - these stamps are invaluable when you get to ordering toys from the very last unlockable catalog as some of the delivery times are around 4 minutes, and this does start to feel like a long time to wait particularly when your toy goes up in a smoke in a number of seconds.There is a story throughout the game which isn't particularly obvious until right at the very end, and I won't include any spoilers here as I think it needs to be played to be experienced. I found it quite moving, and the whole experience very enjoyable.This game is fairly short - I managed to complete it in 3 1/2 hours, but I hadn't worked out all of the stamp combos, and I'm actually already keen to go and play it again so I can work the remaining ones out as some combo names are quite cryptic (whereas some are blatantly obvious).This game is £6.99 on Steam and this is a lot of money for a short game, however I do think if you connect with the gameplay and the story there is scope for replay-ability, and certainly once you've unlocked everything you can just leave it as a 'toy' in itself to pick up and play whenever you fancy burning something on-screen.Little Inferno is simplistic, it looks great, it's fun, it's challenging, it's polished, it's thought-provoking. I really didn't expect it to be as good as it was. I thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish, and would definitely recommend giving it a try. It's something that can be played in one sitting, or something you can come back to, either way it's definitely something that should be experienced.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Little Inferno is something of a commentary on the concept of in-app purchases in modern gaming, and never quite seems to reach its potential with the idea. At its core, this is a puzzle game where you're trying to find certain combinations of items to burn, where clues are given to you to suggest the items you should be burning. Other than that, it's a matter of burning everything you can to get more money to buy more things to burn them. Sound familiar?Despite its simple premise, the game is oddly addictive (a damning enough statement on the skinner boxes that are modern video games unto itself), and can be a good bit of fun for the short times it lasts.The music is good, the ending is a little odd, but the game is definitely worth a look - probably on sale.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This is a very fun game about burning stuff. Some of the combinations are well thought out and even the ones that aren't are fun to look for. If you like watching things explode and absurd imagery you'll like this game. The ending is sweet and satisfying and the game play is fun even though it's extremely simple in concept. Partially this is due to the art direction being very consistent throughout the game. I had a lot more fun playing this game with a friend or two in the room coming up with silly combinations to burn with me.The game benefits from knowing just how weird its premise is and running with it.Unfortunately once you've gotten all the combinations it doesn't have a lot of replay value as the story is linear and there are a set number of specialized interactions. But it takes awhile to get all those combinations and it's more than worth it for that first play through.It also runs on well on even low powered machines. I could get this game to run on my net book which barely runs Microsoft Word.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This is by far the best game I have purchased in a long time. The premise is odd, basically you just set stuff on fire in a little fireplace, but it is so much more than that. The item descriptions are hysterical, and the item animations as they catch fire made me laugh a number of times. I bought this game on whim during the Summer Sale, and loaded it up one night. I looked up a little bit later only to realize that two hours had gone by, with me just giggling and setting things on fire. I can only hope that there is a sequel of some kind to come. Kudos to the developers, I love you guys.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												The problem with Little Inferno is that it burns out too quickly, even after three hours. It kept me shocked during the first hour and a half, alternating between dumb Beavis and Butthead antics and slow-burning horror. Then the game wants you to find combos to progress and it turns into a Tim Burton-shaped grind, ruining whatever momentum it built up. All it needed was Johnny Depp telling the player that NINE MORE COMBOS ARE NEEDED TO PROGRESS, SIRRAH (DOES A FUNNY DANCE) to perfectly emulate Tim Burton's descent into chiaroscuro-tinted underperformance.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2013
												One of the most heart-warming (ha!) games I've played in a long time. The goal of the game is to burn items in inventive combinations; as you do so, the game's story slowly reveals itself. You can't help but to fall in love with the characters, even though you only meet them face-to-face in the final moments of the game. The art is goofy and beautiful, the humor is snappy and perverse, and the video message at the end of the first act will haunt your dreams for a week. Doesn't have much replay value because the story is tied to the sandbox mode. But if you aren't like me and can totally ignore the story, replay value is nearly infinite. Put it on your wishlist, wait for a sale, and enjoy.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Little Inferno is something of a commentary on the concept of in-app purchases in modern gaming, and never quite seems to reach its potential with the idea. At its core, this is a puzzle game where you're trying to find certain combinations of items to burn, where clues are given to you to suggest the items you should be burning. Other than that, it's a matter of burning everything you can to get more money to buy more things to burn them. Sound familiar?Despite its simple premise, the game is oddly addictive (a damning enough statement on the skinner boxes that are modern video games unto itself), and can be a good bit of fun for the short times it lasts.The music is good, the ending is a little odd, but the game is definitely worth a look - probably on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Little Inferno is a charming one.If you had any previous experience with World of Goo, you should know exactly what to expect out of this little piece's flavor and aesthetics. For many small games, there is a point where, for the sake of keeping up with the challenges the gameplay introduces, the player's mind effectively strips away the colorful facade of it, revealing the core mechanics to be yet another twist on an ages old arcade, which it is perceived as from there on. Here, that's hardly the case.Then again, the complexity of Little Inferno's gameplay is somewhere between that of Clicker Heroes and a bubble wrap simulator. Yet, given how deeply satisfying the look and feel of this trivial process proves, and how the occasional story shards keep popping up at just the right moments, this simplicity manages to give birth to some mesmerizing immersion.The visuals are freakishly grotesque and disarmingly adorable at the same time, and the beautiful soundtrack contributes overwhelming emotionality to the process. Invest in it just a bit, click away the build-up, and you find yourself at the story's climax, gasping for every little final detail like a revelation.Little Inferno is a cozy place to be. The flames will consume you whole. But that's okay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												The trailers don't lie. The core, and only, gameplay mechanic is "place things into fireplace and ignite". However....What an interesting world they've created! It's shockingly immersive. Leetle Inferno does a wonderful job of defining a tone and setting with minimal effort. Rarely have I felt so directly connected to a game's protagonist. What leetle plot/character development exists is suprisingly compelling. As the story is so brief and simplistic, to say pretty much anything would be a spoiler. But to indicate that a game in which the only action you can take is to burn things in a fireplace is even capable of having spoilers should be compelling enough.Leetle Inferno is simultaneously comforting, creepy, inspirational and depressing. I've completed the game and am still unsure whether or not it's "fun". If "unique" or "interesting" is enough for you, it's well worth a $10 sale price.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
An experience"Little Inferno" is unique. The only game I can think of that is similar is "Papers, Please". The gameplay really takes a backseat  in this game. But the way the story unfolds around you is amazing. You regularily get letters that tell the story, while sitting at your fire without seeing anything else but your fireplace.Although the gameplay really gets repetitive after a while and the waiting implemented as "shipping times" kinda gets annoying, the story makes up for it. Even though I only played it once a few months ago, the story sticked and still has an impact on me even now.So if it's on sale and you have time to sit down for a few hours, let yourself get immersed by this amazing journey with an amazingly cute artstyle, a uniquely told story and a connection to the characters without ever meeting any of them I have never seen before!

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												A game about burning things. Burn things to buy more things to burn! The game has an anti-consumerism message, saying that there is more to life than just sitting in front of a fireplace, but the ending is mostly left open to interpretation. Some of the later-game combos are fairly obtuse and I looked them up to figure out the required items. Fire physics are very nice, and some of the items are very fun and creepy.

The story of Little Inferno may feel odd at first, but soon becomes exiting, then sad, then heart warming. Play this game, you will spend hours burning everything, and not know where all the time went.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
I'd like to start by saying if there were a "Mixed" option, I'd pick that for my recommendation.I can't say I can really call this a good game so much as I call it a fun toy. The fire physics are fun to play with, and this game is guaranteed to make the pyromaniac inside you cackle with glee as you burn stuff. Some items are fun just to play with instead of just burn right away (Manly Razer comes to mind). A lot of the things react in unique ways when burned, others... do nothing at all. But if you ever wanted to burn an opera lady or a pirate or... well, this is the place to do it. In that regard, Little Inferno is fun. Some people will say that's enough. It's made more appealing by the story that goes along with it, told through the letters you receive from three different people. While I kinda like the story itself, some of the themes lose their impact due to their overly repetitive nature. I invite you to take a shot every time someone mentions something not lasting forever or never being able to go back.Another thing I don't really understand is why after buying something, you have to wait for it to ship to you. Some items take a few seconds, others take a couple minutes (I believe the longest you'll wait for an item is five minutes). So if you run out of stuff to burn and are waiting for your next batch to arrive, the gameplay grinds to a halt, leaving you sitting there like a putz while you wait for your stuff. If you happen to get some Tomorrow Bucks, you can use those to skip the shipping time, but the game is very stingy about handing them out. The best way to get more is by finding combos, which is also required to unlock the other catalogs. Oh, and did I mention after buying something, not only does it take a while for it to ship to you, but it takes even longer to restock?So to some degree, it feels like I'm playing a free to play game where if I don't have or don't want to spend money (or Tomorrow Bucks in this case), I have to wait to keep playing. I'm not convinced that's a good choice of gameplay mechanic. At least it isn't riddled with microtransactions like free to play games.I wouldn't say Little Inferno is bad, but my biggest gripe is the waiting system; it's just an unnecessary feature that gets in the way of what's otherwise a fun little experience. You'll have an enjoyable time when you're not waiting for more things to burn. I think the story is the strongest point of the game, even though themes are repeated to the point of losing most of their impact.You're more than likely to play this game, finish the story, maybe mess around with burning stuff for a little while, and then get bored and uninstall it. Worth checking out, but I suggest you wait for a sale; this fun toy of a game isn't worth full price.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												It took me 3 hours and 20 minutes to complete the game start to finish. I really enjoyed every second of it! It's a fun, quirky game, but underneath that exterior is the truth behind our own world and culture.Yes, it might seem extreme for us now to be burning our things in a furnace, but it showed how completely wasteful we are inheriently as human beings. I personally loved all the different combinations and seeing what effect it has when I set something on fire. Some of the combo's were so cute and cleverly picked. It will test your creative thinking skills to figure out the different combinations based only on the title clues. The graphics are one of the best parts, I loved the colorful characters and then at the very end to the contrast of the black/grey/white somber feel. It looked so beautiful. I really enjoyed this art style.Overall, great game! Once you beat the game there's not much use out of it, but it was a good way to spend 3 1/2 hours! If you're into these sort of games, grab little inferno!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												As someone who loved World of Goo about as much as someone can possibly love a game, buying this was a no-brainer. But should you do the same? I'm not sure. This is definitely one of those "love it or hate it" games (if it can even be called a game). I personally loved it, but I wonder how many others will. On one hand, the gameplay consists of burning things... lots and lots of things. This is an act of primal enjoyment for most human beings. But on the other hand, that's really all there is to it (for the most part). I mean that literally - the entire 4+ hour game consists of burning things in a fireplace. I know that sounds boring, but it's actually kind of not. It's fun to throw different items in to see what they do, and finding combinations of items that, when burned together, reward you with tons of cash and more items. How much mileage others will get out of that experience I can't even being to predict. Aside from burning things, the only other notable aspect of the game is its story (which for 90% of the time takes place more in the background). The end of the game changes this significantly, but I shan't say more about that ;). The story is a sort of societal commentary built of mounds of metaphors (some subtle, some not so much), with a major revelation at the end... basically, it's the kind of thing that goes over well with the "artsy" crowd. I dug it, but again, I'm just not sure how that translates to a mainstream audience. It does, however, lend itself perfectly to the overall atmosphere of the experience (along with the unique art style and music).If you're open to unique indie experiences and don't mind the $15 price tag, go for it. Just be warned that there's not all that much to it. World of Goo, this most definitely is not - but it's definitely something very unique (in its own very, very weird and addicting way), and all-in-all, a worthy successor.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2012
												Little Inferno looks like a simple, casual game, but it's actually a little deeper than that. Yes, you get to throw stuff into a fireplace. A lot of things, in fact. But way, way into the center of it all there's also a storyline to be found. I won't spoil it so I'll just talk about the gameplay a little bit more. While burning things you'll earn coins and stamps. You see, all items have to be ordered and the stamps will give you the ability to instantly deliver an item to your doorstep. Coins can, of course, be used to buy items or increase the number of objects you can stock. A few hours into the game these items will dramatically increase in price. Now, the real goal is to find and create combos. Combining certain items will unlock an achievement and earn you lots of money. And what for ? To buy new items, you got it ! These combos are a must if you want to complete the game, by the way. Most gamers should be able to finish it in 3,5 hours or so. So it's not all that long, and the time limit for deliveries artificially lengthens the game as well, which is a real shame.The graphics and animations are cute and beautiful. And the fire looks quite amazing, with all the ashes and whatnot. Impressive stuff if you ask me. The music is minimal, but memorable. Especially the Weather Balloon song got my attention.All in all it's a fun game but I wish it was even deeper than this. It's still a bit too shallow for my taste.[Rating: 78/100]

number of helpful: 23 of 44 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I keep a positive approach to indie developers, especially if they already created something I enjoyed. My attitude here was "World of Goo was great. A second game from the same dev? A must have!". And perhaps because of expecting a similar quality of gameplay, I was ultimately underwhelmed.The mentioned gameplay is as simple as it gets. Buy things -> burn them -> receive slightly more money than you spent on it -> buy more things -> repeat ad infinitum. Some items here and there react a bit more interestingly then others when burned, but in the case of most of them it's about what you'd expect - they catch fire, turn to ash, end.There's no challenge, no timer, no optional objectives a la WoG's OCDs, nothing that really requires you to pay attention. It is definitely much more casual than WoG, though not necessarily more family friendly - some toys screaming (even if cartoonishly) when burned "alive" can be quite creepy. Which is good, as it helps stay awake during the game.The game is short - which wouldn't be bad by itself, but it's short despite being already artificially dragged out by time delays between buying items and receiving them (from several second at first to up to about 4,5 minutes for more expensive items). Game takes about 3h to finish, whereas it would take perhaps 30 minutes without the waiting times - and it would be a considerably more enjoyable experience in that case. Between a 30 minutes of well-paced engaging fun and a 3h game in which I regularly alt-tab to keep myself busy while waiting for cooldowns to end, I'd take the former any day.To give credit where credit is due, the game is visually pleasing + has a theme song I occasionally catch myself humming. There is definitely a good dose of creativity put into the aesthetics of Little Inferno. But though I don't regret playing it, I find it hard to recommend to anyone due to the ultimately dull and unrewarding gameplay.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Neat casual game that's good to kill your time. You're given a fireplace and an eternal, somehow, lighter. Your job is to burn as many things as you can to earn coins and finding combos.Getting combos is how you move forward, and the trickiest of them all. If you don't cheat by looking at FAQ list, this can be time consuming. To buy the next recipe list you must complete a certain number of combos - going to be irritating if you can't get that last hint and find the combo.The artificial timer intended to stop you from doing combos too fast is also annoying. Well, it's the weakest part of the game IMHO.Game has no storyline except some obscure dialogues between silent protagonist (you), weather news reporter.... and an annoying neighbor.Overall not worth full price though - and this game's bundle material so you might want to wait and clear your backlog before purchasing.6/10

number of helpful: 22 of 42 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												While I very much like the effort and ideas that went into this game, it's just really tedious.The "game" part of course involves burning items one by one to progress the story. As long as you just burn one of each item, you'll get to the end. Each item has a "delivery timer", which makes the "game" go fairly slowly. Discovering combos gives you the ability to speed up these timers, but that's the ONLY thing finding the combos actually provides.I figured something more would happen when I unlocked all the combos and was pretty disappointed that the Combos are otherwise completely pointless and just meaningless padding to turn what would otherwise be an hour-long game into a few hours of trial-and-error (some of the combos make sense, others are VERY obtuse).After burning one of each item, you get a long cutscene at the end that starts great and should have ended after the first 2 minutes, but then goes on try too hard to have multiple layers of meaning. The surface meaning of "don't waste your life playing video games" is enough, they really shouldn't have tried so hard otherwise at the end.All in all, I'd say that while it's a great looking game, it's just not really worth the effort to "play".

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I loved this game so much it compelled me to actually write a review. I've never done that. What started out as a fun-enough little novelty game about burning things, slowly evolved into one of the most unique, interesting, engaging and moving gaming experiences I've ever had. While you're merrily going along, thoughtlessly setting fire to all manner of objects, (and attempting to figure out some of the charming little burn combos along the way) you'll notice the game is beginning to draw you in on a deeper level. There is a story here. There is someone to care about. There are quirky and interesting characters, and ultimately there is an ending which is thought-provoking, humorous, and beautiful.I highly recommend this game. Come for the fire. Stay for the warmth.

												A small, haunting little game.  The core mechanic is for you to puzzle out unique combinations of items to burn together, based on clues, which then allows you to unlock catalogs containing even more, increasingly strange items to burn. I haven't completed the game yet, but I am drawn back to it like a month to a flame.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2013
												A small, haunting little game.  The core mechanic is for you to puzzle out unique combinations of items to burn together, based on clues, which then allows you to unlock catalogs containing even more, increasingly strange items to burn.  Rinse, repeat.  However, during the course of the game, a depressing story with dark undertones beguns to unfold through messages sent to you from neighbors who are also sitting around, burning things in their fireplaces.Little Inferno took me by surprise.  It's deceptively simple, yet I suddenly found myself with over 2 hours invested into it my first time around.  It went very fast.  I haven't completed the game yet, but I am drawn back to it like a month to a flame.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Review for Little InfernoNow this game is something special.The game is simple,basic and in general and easy game. There is no objective,you are not being timed. You burn toys and eventually other items. You do so to get coins to buy more things to burn. You basically just sit there beside a cozy fire infront of your computer.  Now I will be talking about the end so be careful when reading this there will be spoilers So the game introduces you to a set of charachters early on, making you not feel so lonely. These charachters give you comfort and will not dissapoint you. The main charachter introduced in this set would be sugar plums. Now she is something special, she will keep sending you mails, and you soon become friends that keep sending eachother items to burn. Now the other charachter is Ms Nancy she is the head of a corporation called Tomorrow corporation, the maker of the Little Inferno fire place. Now she will introduce you to the shop system. And the last charachter would be The weather man. He gives updates on the current situation outsides and gives you a rough idea on what is happening outside and why you should make your fires to keep cozy.The simplicity adds many hours added to your play count. Beside the fact of not being timed, you have all the time in the world, find all the combos, a system to keep the player puzzeled and entertained.The game isnt perfect of course. The simplicity does make the game worse in some ways. The game is short but furfilling.You will feel satisfied when you finish, due to the atmospheric and intriquing ending of the game.Talking about atmospheric the game has a fantastic artstyle which you have never seen. This game,with its artstyle, will keep you cozy,calm and intriqued. The mails that you keep getting sent will keep you company and will make you feel like you arent alone in this heartless cold world, that seems to have no hope. Now there is a bother in this game, the wait times. Without doing the combos, which you should if you have time, the game will be a long game with wait times that last to 6 minutes. Now the good news logging off would save your progress and save the time , atleast it did for me. Now the ending. The ending is introduced rather slowly. Sugar plumbs will slowly push you towards the end, explaining what has happened to her, will happen to you. The last catalog was her end and you know this as you progress through the game. Now the ending requires you to know the items you send to her over the course of this game. But surprisingly this isnt a hard task, at all. You will remember the items, unless certain conditions. Just due to the unique charachter that she poses to be. The end ties up all the loose strings and as said will make you feel satisfied.I would if I had to rate this game give it a 7/10 Its not something fantastic that would add TONS of replay value. But it is unique and has kept me on my toes, making me pay attention to every damn detail.-Newdles Way over the smoke stacks, over the city Newdles

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is very unique. It's not quite a puzzle game, not quite an action game, not quite a sandox game, not quite a simulation game. However, it manages to keep my attention for a good amount of time, and the art is very attractive.Little Inferno offers this subtle-but-not-quite-subtle insight on society. It reminds me of the Ray Bradbury novel "Fahrenheit 451" in which books are burned and TV is watched all day. Little Inferno and "Fahrenheit 451" both share a satirical undertone exploiting and mocking society.Another thing I like about Little Inferno is just how satisfying the entire game is. I never thought playing with fire could be so much fun! (Little Inferno - Condoning pyromania since 2012!)Altogether, Little Inferno is executed very nicely and is definitely worth taking a look at.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												     Little Inferno is a simple puzzler game made by Tomorrow Corporation. The game consists if you sitting in front of a fireplace or "The Little Inferno" and you simple burn items that you can purchase through catalog. You can purchase items with coins that you receive from burning other items. You always get more coins then you spent when you burn something. The game keeps you going with "alchemy" style combining such as many iOS games such as Doodle God. These combinations are called combos and you have to try and figure out the combos by the name suggested. For example the combo the Easter Bunny combo would require you to burn a bunch of eggs and a stuffed bunny toy together.      These simple mechanics could get repetitive for some; but personally the combo system kept me going. The game may be simple in mechanics and it's not too challenging, but it delivers a strong message about how you should spend your time. Little Inferno is a unique indie game with about 3-4 hours of solid gameplay that makes you rethink certain things you do in everyday life. With all that said I feel that it is definitely worth the solid price of 9.99$

												This game is probably not worth buying. And a lot of people pan it for the wrong reasons, A lot of people hate the wait times and fake microtransactions the game uses to poke at ♥♥♥♥♥♥ app/facebook games. Although it may not be completely stimulating and enjoyable all the time, which is absolutely an important part of a game, it doesn't make this game BAD. This game is honestly just a little toy to play around with and have some kind of odd and satisfying story presented to you about humans and technology. But is it worth paying 10 bucks for, or 5 bucks for? Maaaybe? I purchased it when it was 20, and felt pretty ripped off. But if you can get it on sale and have any interest in the game, sure, go for it. It might just be special for you.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												A fun little game with lighthearted jokes and an interesting gameplay. It's a game to fiddle around with and you only progress after a certain time of doing just that. The graphics are nice, everything is sleek, the music is fun, and it unleashes your inner arsonist that we all have inside of us. Perfect for kids since it doesn't utilize complex mechanics --just click on what's in your inventory, place it in the furnace, hold the mouse button and BURN BABY BURN!!--or someone older who finds amusement in a charming time-waster such as this. There is no real goal though there are small "objectives" sprinkled here and there as time passes, though you are not bound by them in order to continue your fun.There are achievements for certain combinations of burning items together and whether by themselves or together what results are pretty interesting effects that reflect this game's interpretation of "physics' and 'cause and effect". Overall I'd say that if you want to play something that you could spend hours whittling away at or something to distract you or a kid for a few minutes, then this is the game to get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Hrm, where to begin. This is kind of a game? More of a practice of design and artistic statement than a game. There really is not much to Little Inferno. You are a kid and you buy things to burn in your Little Inferno fireplace to stay warm. That's it. It feels like a moble mini-transaction game, but it isn't. I cannot say it is fun, but it is certainly interesting. Well, it is kinda fun for the first little while and getting to see all the different items burned, but this is very short lived. There is something more to it, something that you have to slog through the "game" to find. But this is very intentional to the overall design, so I cannot say that this is a bad thing as you are suppose to become bored and disenchanted with it and it is only after that where the true statement of the game lies. It does what it is designed to do very well. It is very different, certainly not for everyone. But based solely on it's intended purpose and design, it does it very well. So I give it 70/100.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I loved this game so much it compelled me to actually write a review. I've never done that. What started out as a fun-enough little novelty game about burning things, slowly evolved into one of the most unique, interesting, engaging and moving gaming experiences I've ever had. While you're merrily going along, thoughtlessly setting fire to all manner of objects, (and attempting to figure out some of the charming little burn combos along the way) you'll notice the game is beginning to draw you in on a deeper level. There is a story here. There is someone to care about. There are quirky and interesting characters, and ultimately there is an ending which is thought-provoking, humorous, and beautiful.I highly recommend this game. Come for the fire. Stay for the warmth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												Little Inferno is a delightfully relaxing little game. There's really not much to it. Toss things in the fireplace, set them ablaze, enjoy the spectacle, and just keep adding to the pile. There's no fancy gimmicks, no fail states, no time limits. Just you, your fireplace, some awesome tunes and visuals, and the simple, yet effective narrative that unfolds as you make progress. Progressing through the game is simple enough: Burn various items together using clues from a list, earn money, and unlock new catalogs. It's entirely stress free, and you'll always have enough money to just enjoy the simple act of burning items and witnessing their unique interactions with one another. There's no need to rush it, just have a nice chill out session by the virtual fireplace and let things happen as they may. For those that want to enjoy the more "gamey' aspects, there are 100 combinations of items in all to figure out, and the clues are generally presented well enough that massive bouts of trial and error won't be too necessary.  Even when you guess incorrectly, the visuals and chill ambience Little Inferno provides still make the experience wholly satisfying. Definitely a game to just chill out with after a hard day's work or when you're feeling stressed.

												You like marvellously weird humor? You have maybe played the game World of Goo? Then this is a game for you!Basically you have to burn things! First of all I looked at some videos to understand the gameplay before I brought the game. It's all about burning things in combination.An example: You get money for burning things and you have to ""level"" your character. You level while you're doing combinations like burning a Cat and a Fish together in your furnace to get a combo "Cat Fish".After you have done a certain amount of combos you are able to buy new things for new combos.The comic look feels unique and fits into the entire game. The effects of fire and like are really awesome. The game has a story - simple but full of humor.Shamelessly there are no achievements for this game. I'm not sure why there are no achievements, because the developers have enough potential to create achievements for this game. Some proposals would be:"Rich man", where you have to collect a certain amount of money."Poor man", where you have no money in your pocket."Crammed", where you have put your entire furnace full of things.etc.Recommended!, even if it's not on sale and has no achievements.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game gets a slight recommendation, and here's why.It's not your typical game. It's one of those "games as art" type of things. The whole concept of the game is you order stuff from a catalog, and set it on fire. Poof! You get coins to order new things, and stamps to get them to you faster. But it's the subtext that's interesting. Your burning things like toys at first, but then you start burning, TVs, radios, e-mail, etc, almost as if you're burning away everything in your life. Get me?And there's also an environmental message in here because the game keeps talking about smoky skies and how it's been snowing for as long as anyone can remember. Hmm.....wonder what that could be, eh?It's not worth $9.99, not at all. It's interesting but it only took me 4-5 hours over the course of two days to beat it. Get it on sale if you must try it out, and you should, because it's a unique game. But don't expect a deep challenge or extraordinary gameplay. This is about as simple as it gets.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												When this was announced I debated with myself whether I should buy it or not. I liked World of Goo, one of the dev's previous games, and this one looked fun as well. The release came and went and I gradually forgot about Little Inferno. Eventually it would show up  in a Humble Bundle which I decided to get. Here is what I thought:Pros: + It's really satisfying to burn things. + The music fits the game. + It was fun trying to get all of the combos. + The game's not just about burning things, there's a meaning behind it all.Cons: - It takes a  few hours to beat.You might want to wait for a sale since this game doesn't really take long to beat.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is one of my favorite things I have ever experienced, ever!The art style and tone is like a mixture between Dr. Suess and Tim Burton, and there's not much else like it in that regard; the goofy yet also rather creepy and unsettling mood.If you like sandbox-style games, and/or fire, this is for you! I have spent an inordinate amount of time just aimlessly burning things, even after having beaten the game several times! There's light puzzles, and stuff along those lines for completionists, but this is really all about the experience. And there's something more dangerous than fire. But what could it be?

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												The gameplay focusses on burning objects and buying new ones. There are waiting times for items, which can go up to 5 minutes. Luckily, you can skip those if you have some cards you obtain from finding combos, or sometimes at random. You have an infinite supply of money. This is because the items you burn drop MAGICAL golden coins, more than you bought the item with. There's a deep message I won't spoil, but pay attention to the story well. The lighting is beautiful and fairy-tale like. The objects you can burn often have special effects. (Such as popcorn) The only downside I see to this is that people might get bored of the repetetive gameplay, which is kinda part of the game. If you don't find it appealing to burn items over and over for hours, don't buy it. If you would like that, or just are a pyromaniac, buy it post-haste. I rate this an 8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												Little Inferno is an enjoyable little game whose story is more compelling than the gameplay. Its feature is burning stuff and doing so in various combonations to earn the right to progress further into the game. The thrill of burning things, itself, is limited. By the time you unlock the second or third catalog of items to burn, you've got the idea and experienced pretty much the extent of it.Little Inferno's story -- told through letters delivered on a regular basis -- is what keeps you burning things and searching for the right pairings of items to match the list of combos it offers you. While the story is compelling, it is not necessarily ultimately satisfying. After about three hours, you'll have completed the game and consumed its somewhat cryptic story and not-so-cryptic parable (yes, there is a life lesson that it's trying to convey to you).I can't advise this game for someone looking for a solid puzzle game. There's just not enough content to last long. If you're interested in a fairly clever little story told through interesting  means, then it's definitely worth trying. Regardless of what you're looking to get out of it, I don't know that it can quite justify its full price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												A fun little game with lighthearted jokes and an interesting gameplay. It's a game to fiddle around with and you only progress after a certain time of doing just that. The graphics are nice, everything is sleek, the music is fun, and it unleashes your inner arsonist that we all have inside of us. Perfect for kids since it doesn't utilize complex mechanics --just click on what's in your inventory, place it in the furnace, hold the mouse button and BURN BABY BURN!!--or someone older who finds amusement in a charming time-waster such as this. There is no real goal though there are small "objectives" sprinkled here and there as time passes, though you are not bound by them in order to continue your fun.There are achievements for certain combinations of burning items together and whether by themselves or together what results are pretty interesting effects that reflect this game's interpretation of "physics' and 'cause and effect". Overall I'd say that if you want to play something that you could spend hours whittling away at or something to distract you or a kid for a few minutes, then this is the game to get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												When I was little I almost set my house on fire with a magnifying glass. I feel the need to disclose that because I think it shows that I have a subconscious bias towards a game such as Little Inferno, which rewards you for experimenting with setting things on fire. That being said I honestly do think this charming little pyro simulator is worth your time and money. The actual burning of things is very entertaining and dare I say relaxing. The fire is very pleasing visually and the items you burn often have very interesting reactions to the immolation. My only gripe with the core mechanic is that the grinding to get all the secret fire combinations can be a bit tedious, and for a few really obscure combinations I had to resort to the internet. At the end of it all though, you’re treated to a truly touching narrative conclusion, while that final cutscene was playing I had genuine chills running down my spine. For all the silly, fiery goodness, the conclusion to the tale was what made me completely satisfied with my purchase.
