												A truly remarkable game. Little Inferno starts off as funny, charming, clever and entertaining, but eventually evolves into an engaging plot that occaisonally pulls at your heartstrings and forces you to ask yourself things you never thought you would in a "sandbox" game. The ending offers a different sort of gameplay, that finishes the storyline like a perfect symphony. The best feature though, is the ability to play in sandbox mode even after the close of the story. Little Inferno is both a visually and narratively beautiful game and is completely worth its cost.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												Little Inferno is an oddball. It's funny, it's quirky, it's dark, and it's disconcerting. It's also short. I finished it in just under five hours, and you could probably shave a few hours off of that if you ignored all but the required number of Combo Badges. On top of which, there's very little here to call a proper game, and gameplay mostly just consists of placing things in the fireplace, and then burning them for fun and prizes. "Prizes" in this case referring to more things to burn, money with which to buy more things to burn, and stamps for speeding up the delivery of more things to burn.It's the ciiiircle of liiiife! And it burns us aaaall!That said, there's a lot of variety to make it interesting, and you're never really positive how a new item will react when you set it on fire or throw it around. I burnt a floppy disk, which caused my fire to become pixelated, and a coffee cup I set ablaze spontaneously grew a face and began screaming. Which brings me to a point: This game is disturbing when it wants to be. On the whole, though, it's all cartoony enough that I think you won't leave your comfort zone.The categories of items are interesting. There's a video game category, of course, and it contains little references, like World of Goo goo balls and a tablet which displays a Duck Hunt nod. My favorite category, however, is the one filled with manly things, such as a monster truck, a flamethrowing chainsaw, and a moustache. And I burned them all.So, what's the point? Well, besides just burning things and seeing what happens (which is kind of its own reward), there are 99 2- or 3-item combos to figure out based on the combo's name alone. These will probably take up the majority of your time. There is also, actually, a plot, told mainly through letters until the endgame, which is... surprisingly different. The ending does what it needs to. It won't answer that feeling you'll get while playing the game that there's something bigger going on here than just people keeping warm, but it gives you a personal conclusion that's a little more than "Try to guess what happened for yourself!" Which, considering the tendencies of indie games these days, is a glorious gift.There's an underlying message to be picked up on, as well. It's a message which rings true, and while it's one that I've seen in various forms in indie games before, I think this is the best presentation I've seen it given, yet.Little Inferno's a short game, but it's good entertainment, if pretty basic in the gameplay department. It'll hold your attention until it's over, but if you're worried about the short length over price, well, that's what Steam sales are for.

												Little Inferno is a game where you progress by purchasing and burning various objects while getting combos and earning more money.I had expected a terrible game after reading some of the reviews. I hated Doodle God with a passion, and Little Inferno has similar gameplay. However, I found myself loving this game for its short duration. A bit of the time is spent waiting for items to arrive... you really have to manage time well to avoid sitting and doing nothing.Thankfully, everything else makes up for the gameplay. The story, graphics, and sound are on par with World of Goo, which was phenomenal. Overall, I found this to be a very enjoyable experience, and I'd recommend it to anyone that can enjoy a more patient game. Wait for it to go on sale, though... I beat it in only a few hours.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Little InfernoThis review was last edited when I had finished the gameShort ReviewAn unusual & amusing game where you throw items into a fire and watch them burn whilst trying to work out combos of things to burn from cryptic clues. It's much better than it sounds. Recommended. Long ReviewYou spend the entire first part of the game with a view of a fireplace where you can drag items and drop them and right click to produce a flame that can then be used to light (some) objects in the fire place.You purchase items from a catalog, further items become available as you purchase different items and extra catalogs can be purchased once all the items from a previous catalog have been purchased and you have completed a certain number of combos. You perform a combo when you burn certain things together at the same time. Purchased items are then delivered to your home and appear as boxes on a bar underneath the fireplace. There is a cool down time before you can open the box and drag the item onto the fireplace, although you can use up cards which drop from time to time in the fireplace to reduce the cool down to zero. You can only store (& so purchase) a set number of items at a time.Cards always drop when you find a combo for the first time. There is a list of cryptic clues to combos available and as you find each combo it is crossed off. A lot of the fun of the game is trying to figure out what items are part of combos.Once the items have been destroyed in the fireplace coins also drop (more than you paid for the item) and you can collect these.As well as purchasing items & catalogs coins can be used to upgrade the space used to store items so hold additional items.Letters also appear "randomly" in your item slots. These offer cryptic clues to the background story, request certain items be sent or deliver additional items.The way the things burn in the fireplace is roughly realistic so some physics simulation is involved. There are interesting items like planets which have their own gravity, bombs which explode etc.At the start of the game you have given hints to explain the game mechanics but to be honest its pretty simple and easy to pick up.There comes a point when the game fundamentally changes and you leave the room with the fire and get to wander around a small town in an adventure style game. To be honest I found this less interesting and only spent half an hour or so looking round before finding the point to finish the game and doing so.Progress is saved when you exit and it's possible to have multiple game progress saved.All in all a surprisingly entertaining game, which my 3 year old loved sitting on my knee and watching, getting very excited when letters arrived & pointing out the things he wanted me to burn .. Hmm thinking about it now maybe I might regret this later in his life ..ProsAmusing game playEasy to pick up and put downSurprisingly addictiveConsI found some combos impossible to work outMarks Out Of 55) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted1) Not worth getting even if given away freePlatform Played OnIntel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse & Steelseries MERC keyboard. My best guess for a  PEGI Rating 12: It has an ESRB[www.esrb.org] rating of Teen.  PEGI Ratings [www.pegi.info]

												This is a very simple game: Burn things to earn money, spend money to buy things to burn, find combos, etc. But just 5 minutes in, and it becomes addicting. Despite it's minimalism, you can tell a lot of care went into the game. From the unique ways each item burns, to the combo system, to the corky dialouge. Now, the game doesn't have the same length World of Goo had. I'm 5 hours into the game right now and I've earned gold status (another clever way to get you hooked on buying items) on everything in the catalouge and only have 10 combos left to discover. But if you find this item on sale, $5 is well worth the purchase. Heck, $10 is even worth it if you plan to play it more than once (and HINT, you will have a reason too). This will indulge your basic human desire to burn things for hours. I recommend it highly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Little Inferno is an odd quasi-puzzle game with a similar style and consumerism narrative as World of Goo, 2D Boy's previous acclaimed release. The player is simply tasked with ordering items from a catalog and then burning them in the Little Inferno fireplace. The challenge comes from unlocking more advanced item catalogs, which require a certain amount of burn combinations to access, but you're really here to just be a virtual pyromaniac. Item design is excellent -- I love the screams from the school bus -- and the game's gradually unfolding story (told via snailmail letters) keeps you enthralled to the end. Little Inferno lacks the replayability of World of Goo, but it's an excellent experience on its own.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												Little Inferno is a delightfully relaxing little game. There's really not much to it. Toss things in the fireplace, set them ablaze, enjoy the spectacle, and just keep adding to the pile. There's no fancy gimmicks, no fail states, no time limits. Just you, your fireplace, some awesome tunes and visuals, and the simple, yet effective narrative that unfolds as you make progress. Progressing through the game is simple enough: Burn various items together using clues from a list, earn money, and unlock new catalogs. It's entirely stress free, and you'll always have enough money to just enjoy the simple act of burning items and witnessing their unique interactions with one another. There's no need to rush it, just have a nice chill out session by the virtual fireplace and let things happen as they may. For those that want to enjoy the more "gamey' aspects, there are 100 combinations of items in all to figure out, and the clues are generally presented well enough that massive bouts of trial and error won't be too necessary.  Even when you guess incorrectly, the visuals and chill ambience Little Inferno provides still make the experience wholly satisfying. Definitely a game to just chill out with after a hard day's work or when you're feeling stressed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Hrm, where to begin. This is kind of a game? More of a practice of design and artistic statement than a game. There really is not much to Little Inferno. You are a kid and you buy things to burn in your Little Inferno fireplace to stay warm. That's it. It feels like a moble mini-transaction game, but it isn't. I cannot say it is fun, but it is certainly interesting. Well, it is kinda fun for the first little while and getting to see all the different items burned, but this is very short lived. There is something more to it, something that you have to slog through the "game" to find. But this is very intentional to the overall design, so I cannot say that this is a bad thing as you are suppose to become bored and disenchanted with it and it is only after that where the true statement of the game lies. It does what it is designed to do very well. It is very different, certainly not for everyone. But based solely on it's intended purpose and design, it does it very well. So I give it 70/100.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I loved this game so much it compelled me to actually write a review. I've never done that. What started out as a fun-enough little novelty game about burning things, slowly evolved into one of the most unique, interesting, engaging and moving gaming experiences I've ever had. While you're merrily going along, thoughtlessly setting fire to all manner of objects, (and attempting to figure out some of the charming little burn combos along the way) you'll notice the game is beginning to draw you in on a deeper level. There is a story here. There is someone to care about. There are quirky and interesting characters, and ultimately there is an ending which is thought-provoking, humorous, and beautiful.I highly recommend this game. Come for the fire. Stay for the warmth.

content:

Português abaixoLIttle Inferno is not a game; or, better saying, is not just a game. Of course it's funny, and will consume a couple of hour (about five) to finish. But that is not what is most important here. This is a gaming experience that intendes to discuss game experience itself, and postmodern life, and global warming, and nihilism... It's a complexe and vast critical material about life and human behavior. If you are not interested in the concept of the game, or thinking about deep things, you can still buy it (as it's fun to burn things and find combos); but, in this case, the game price is a little high, and you should wait a promotion to aquire it.----------------Little Inferno não é um jogo; ou, melhor dizendo, não é só um jogo. É claro que é divertido, e irá consumir algumas horas (por volta de cinco) jogar até o final. Mas isso não é o mais importante aqui. Little Inferno é uma experiência que pretende discutir a própria indústria de videogames, e a vida pós-moderna, e o aquecimento global, e o niilismo... É uma crítica complexa e extensa sobre a vida e o comportamento humano.Se você não está interessado no conceito do jogo, ou não quer pensar sobre temas profundos, você ainda pode comprar o jogo (ainda é extremamente divertido queimar coisas e descobrir combos); mas, nesse caso, o preço do jogo está alto, e vale a pena esperar uma promoção.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												     Little Inferno is a simple puzzler game made by Tomorrow Corporation. The game consists if you sitting in front of a fireplace or "The Little Inferno" and you simple burn items that you can purchase through catalog. You can purchase items with coins that you receive from burning other items. You always get more coins then you spent when you burn something. The game keeps you going with "alchemy" style combining such as many iOS games such as Doodle God. These combinations are called combos and you have to try and figure out the combos by the name suggested. For example the combo the Easter Bunny combo would require you to burn a bunch of eggs and a stuffed bunny toy together.      These simple mechanics could get repetitive for some; but personally the combo system kept me going. The game may be simple in mechanics and it's not too challenging, but it delivers a strong message about how you should spend your time. Little Inferno is a unique indie game with about 3-4 hours of solid gameplay that makes you rethink certain things you do in everyday life. With all that said I feel that it is definitely worth the solid price of 9.99$

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is very unique. It's not quite a puzzle game, not quite an action game, not quite a sandox game, not quite a simulation game. However, it manages to keep my attention for a good amount of time, and the art is very attractive.Little Inferno offers this subtle-but-not-quite-subtle insight on society. It reminds me of the Ray Bradbury novel "Fahrenheit 451" in which books are burned and TV is watched all day. Little Inferno and "Fahrenheit 451" both share a satirical undertone exploiting and mocking society.Another thing I like about Little Inferno is just how satisfying the entire game is. I never thought playing with fire could be so much fun! (Little Inferno - Condoning pyromania since 2012!)Altogether, Little Inferno is executed very nicely and is definitely worth taking a look at.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												WARNING: Do not play with fire!Good folks from World of Goo bring another puzzle game with their idiosyncratic art style and vague motifs of.. anti-consumerism? enviromentalism? anti-corporationalism? being a hippie? ehhhh... O_oAnyway.. World of Goo was a physics puzzle while here, - here we have an object/word association puzzle.You get catalogues of things to burn, and along with a catalogue, you get a list of named combos - and the goal (besides enjoying the.. "burning sensation".. hue) is to guess what things to burn together, based on name of the combo and names/descriptions/behavior in game/presumed functions outside the game/cultural references etc. etc. pertaining to objects from given catalogue and any previously unlocked ones.As such, the game is somewhat culturally biased, and perhaps acts as proof that your command of English language is not as good as you might think it is (not sure about other languages?). Which may be wee bit unfortunate for some... But otherwise this is really enjoyable game, pleasantly tickling your brain!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												First off the game is beautiful graphically. I was shocked to see how well the fire mechanics work and some of the items are really fun to burn or burn together. The burning alone is good for a few hours of fun.The combos are basically the only gameplay. There is no conflict. All you do is gather coins to buy things to burn. Burning 2 or more of certain items at the same time scores a combo which gets you express tickets to get items you buy delivered faster. A certain number of combos are required to unlock new catalogs full of new things to burn. There is a combo list you can reference that gives you hints on items to experiment with.There is a small story wrapped up in the game that reveals itself to you over time. The game also has a pretty decent (if long) ending cutscene/activity to reward you for your efforts.Also, if you are given a coupon for a "Free Hug", you might not want to burn it. Just a hint. It won't break the game if you do though.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2013
												A small, haunting little game.  The core mechanic is for you to puzzle out unique combinations of items to burn together, based on clues, which then allows you to unlock catalogs containing even more, increasingly strange items to burn.  Rinse, repeat.  However, during the course of the game, a depressing story with dark undertones beguns to unfold through messages sent to you from neighbors who are also sitting around, burning things in their fireplaces.Little Inferno took me by surprise.  It's deceptively simple, yet I suddenly found myself with over 2 hours invested into it my first time around.  It went very fast.  I haven't completed the game yet, but I am drawn back to it like a month to a flame.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Review for Little InfernoNow this game is something special.The game is simple,basic and in general and easy game. There is no objective,you are not being timed. You burn toys and eventually other items. You do so to get coins to buy more things to burn. You basically just sit there beside a cozy fire infront of your computer.  Now I will be talking about the end so be careful when reading this there will be spoilers So the game introduces you to a set of charachters early on, making you not feel so lonely. These charachters give you comfort and will not dissapoint you. The main charachter introduced in this set would be sugar plums. Now she is something special, she will keep sending you mails, and you soon become friends that keep sending eachother items to burn. Now the other charachter is Ms Nancy she is the head of a corporation called Tomorrow corporation, the maker of the Little Inferno fire place. Now she will introduce you to the shop system. And the last charachter would be The weather man. He gives updates on the current situation outsides and gives you a rough idea on what is happening outside and why you should make your fires to keep cozy.The simplicity adds many hours added to your play count. Beside the fact of not being timed, you have all the time in the world, find all the combos, a system to keep the player puzzeled and entertained.The game isnt perfect of course. The simplicity does make the game worse in some ways. The game is short but furfilling.You will feel satisfied when you finish, due to the atmospheric and intriquing ending of the game.Talking about atmospheric the game has a fantastic artstyle which you have never seen. This game,with its artstyle, will keep you cozy,calm and intriqued. The mails that you keep getting sent will keep you company and will make you feel like you arent alone in this heartless cold world, that seems to have no hope. Now there is a bother in this game, the wait times. Without doing the combos, which you should if you have time, the game will be a long game with wait times that last to 6 minutes. Now the good news logging off would save your progress and save the time , atleast it did for me. Now the ending. The ending is introduced rather slowly. Sugar plumbs will slowly push you towards the end, explaining what has happened to her, will happen to you. The last catalog was her end and you know this as you progress through the game. Now the ending requires you to know the items you send to her over the course of this game. But surprisingly this isnt a hard task, at all. You will remember the items, unless certain conditions. Just due to the unique charachter that she poses to be. The end ties up all the loose strings and as said will make you feel satisfied.I would if I had to rate this game give it a 7/10 Its not something fantastic that would add TONS of replay value. But it is unique and has kept me on my toes, making me pay attention to every damn detail.-Newdles Way over the smoke stacks, over the city Newdles

												The artstyle of this game alone should justify the purchase of this game. Very well done use of creepy objects/items. The music, sound effects, fire effects... all Beautiful. Controlling the fire is fluent, controlling the objects on screen, simple yet effective. The ONE thing I would change about it is the fact coins and those tickets are involed. Never once in the game did it feel like I was just grinding through trying to get the most coins, the levels and objects were very fun to play with and getting all 99 combos was fun as hell. If you're not going to 100% the combos, this might be an hour long game for your, but it'd be one fun hour indeed.

												Little Inferno, my very first game on Steam. Truly a classic in my books with good reason. What on the outside appears to be a mirror of modern tablet and phone games eventually shows that on the inside it is a game with deeper meaning and much more to offer than a phone game would be able to. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												Little Inferno is a delightfully relaxing little game. There's really not much to it. Toss things in the fireplace, set them ablaze, enjoy the spectacle, and just keep adding to the pile. There's no fancy gimmicks, no fail states, no time limits. Just you, your fireplace, some awesome tunes and visuals, and the simple, yet effective narrative that unfolds as you make progress. Progressing through the game is simple enough: Burn various items together using clues from a list, earn money, and unlock new catalogs. It's entirely stress free, and you'll always have enough money to just enjoy the simple act of burning items and witnessing their unique interactions with one another. There's no need to rush it, just have a nice chill out session by the virtual fireplace and let things happen as they may. For those that want to enjoy the more "gamey' aspects, there are 100 combinations of items in all to figure out, and the clues are generally presented well enough that massive bouts of trial and error won't be too necessary.  Even when you guess incorrectly, the visuals and chill ambience Little Inferno provides still make the experience wholly satisfying. Definitely a game to just chill out with after a hard day's work or when you're feeling stressed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I loved this game so much it compelled me to actually write a review. I've never done that. What started out as a fun-enough little novelty game about burning things, slowly evolved into one of the most unique, interesting, engaging and moving gaming experiences I've ever had. While you're merrily going along, thoughtlessly setting fire to all manner of objects, (and attempting to figure out some of the charming little burn combos along the way) you'll notice the game is beginning to draw you in on a deeper level. There is a story here. There is someone to care about. There are quirky and interesting characters, and ultimately there is an ending which is thought-provoking, humorous, and beautiful.I highly recommend this game. Come for the fire. Stay for the warmth.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												A charming and quirky little tale whose subtle stabs at the time management industry are just as interesting as the dark, apocalyptic, and ultimately hopeful narrative itself.At its surface, Little Inferno is another one of those casual "waiting" games. You're given a virtual fireplace in which you'll burn things. You purchase items from a catalog, burn the items, and receive more coins and stamps in the process to buy more expensive items. You continue the process on repeat, just to fill out an entire catalog page and unlock a new one. At its surface, just like any other time management game, the premise seems idiotic. But somehow, it works. You begin to feed the fire, you get to watch how different items react to the flames, you notice that certain combinations yield certain "achievements" called combos, and just like that the game has already sucked you in. And that's the point.Beyond its surface, this game seems to be a jab at the time we waste on games of the same ilk. As an example, the reward for successfully completing all 99 combos in the game is a "Novelty Mousepad". Essentially, for all that work and for all that time wasted, you receive an item that you can do absolutely nothing with besides burn for more stamps. The game invites you to indulge in its addictive qualities, and then it slaps you in the face for doing so. In my opinion it's brilliantly executed, right down to the oh-so-special "alternate ending".So why should you waste your time with this? If it's a game that makes fun of time management games by being, itself, a time management game, what's the point in playing? Well beyond the superficial gameplay, there's actually a rather moving theme lying beneath the surface. It unravels slowly at first, but the ending scene is something rather special.Beyond the warmth and comfort of your homely fireplace is a ravaged and desolate wasteland, slowly being consumed by unknown causes in the "adult world". You eventually come to realize this as you're stripped away from your Little Inferno, but despite this, despite the inevitable decline you begin to notice around you, you must remember that there's an entire world out there, and you can go as far as you want.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Little Inferno is a quirky and fun game. The main plot takes place in a modern time with a twist. The entire world has frozen over. Cities of people thrive indoors and never step foot outside. A company called Tomorrow Coorporation makes a fireplace for kids to burn their toys in. Yay! We can be warm! But what happens when you run out of toys? You buy more, of course! By buying toys, you can unlock new magazines to buy toys from. During the game, you will recieve letters from different people. Without these, the story would have no plot whatsoever. Miss Nancy, the CEO of Tomorrow Coorporation, your neighbor Sugar Plumps, and the weatherman will all send you letters. These letters may include quests that you MUST do in order for the game's story to continue. They are all simple and the hardest they get is sending a toy to Sugar Plumps.Overall, this game is absolutley brilliant. Burning toys and getting more to burn? Who would have thought of it! Out of 10, I would give this game an 8.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I dunno if the game devs thought "Let's make a game about burning things!" but damn is it fun!Because this is what you do over the course of the entire game. Burn things.If you're like me you can easily spend the rest of your life playing this game. It's just so god damn satsifying to burn all the stuff. And all of the stuff you get to burn!So anyway, the story is:The world is getting colder and it is constantly snowing and nobody knows why. The Tomorrow Corporation has taken it upon themselves to create a device (and a bunch of items for it) that keeps people warm. It is the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace! What do you do with it? You buy things from the company with their currency and burn them in said fireplace!After you burned everything and discovered the hidden combo there's quite a bit of story at the end but I won't spoiler anything.If you're a pyromaniac or you just find it absolutely satisfying to watch things burn (and scream in the process) then I advise you to: GET. THIS. GAME. 10/10, I love it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												So if you were to try to vaguely explain this game to a friend it would probably just be something along the lines of "you burn stuff". But it's more than that, I promise. There's a story of a freezing city and a loose canon neighbor that can get annoying to the general person who doesn't enjoy a casual game. There are combos to achieve and toys to burn. Most of the time, you'll sit there wondering what you're doing with your life. What are you really supposed to be achieveing. And that's the glory of a casual game. But at the end it throws you into an emotional torrent of story with no burning whatsoever. seeing things you never thought you'd see in the game. That's the beauty of it. Little Inferno is not a game I expected to see in my top favorites but stranger things have happened. I highly recommend anyone with a good sense of humor and the patience to play a more simple game give this one a try. Seriously a surprisingly great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Little Inferno is a unique and interesting experience. The gameplay is simple: You buy things, you burn things. It can get quite repeditive but for such a short game it is a rewarding experience. The story is compelling and makes several social commentaries. Including how our gaming culture has evolved. To say anymore would spoil the story which is most important factor as you play; As you continue to buy and burn your life savings away. I wouldn't recommend trying to do all of the combos and star all of the catalogs unless you are very determined. As that is where the games repeditive nature really kicks in.Experience and enjoy the story you are being told. Normally I would say a game this short would not be worth its price, but to the right person this can be a great experience that's worth playing  a few times over.

My one gripe is the lack of settings option within the game to adjust the volume but there is a settings.txt which lets you change the volume easily enough.Besides all this though, there is a definite undertone of social commentary and advice which puts It into the bucket of philosophical game stories along with Braid.

												Little Inferno is a unique and interesting experience. The gameplay is simple: You buy things, you burn things. It can get quite repeditive but for such a short game it is a rewarding experience. The story is compelling and makes several social commentaries. Including how our gaming culture has evolved. To say anymore would spoil the story which is most important factor as you play; As you continue to buy and burn your life savings away. I wouldn't recommend trying to do all of the combos and star all of the catalogs unless you are very determined. As that is where the games repeditive nature really kicks in.Experience and enjoy the story you are being told. Normally I would say a game this short would not be worth its price, but to the right person this can be a great experience that's worth playing  a few times over.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												It`s Little Inferno just for me!This game is a really relaxing one, and it is a ton of fun to play. The most interesting aspect of this game is poperly the story, which you can analyze (or in some cases overanalyze) to have a really deep meaning, but I will get back to that.The gamepaly is really simple you have to burn stuff. And that`s the game, you do nothing more than burning stuff, and it sounds really boring but the game has a fun way, to twist this, so it becomes fun to play.Throughout the game, you will unlock more and more stuff to burn, and all the items have some unic way of burning away, this gives some fun events and senarios, which is enjorable in every way. The other part of the game, is finding combinations. To make the combinations you have to burn specifick things together, in order to unlock the secret. Normally you only get one sentence to geuse, what the combination is, and it is really fun to try to solve the code.Now to the story, the story centers around you, that have got the "Little Inferno intertaining fireplace" which is a toy for children in the games world. You are intreduced to four charecters in the game, and then there is the main charecter, which we get no relation to. We get to know miss Nancy, the creator of the Little Inferno, The weather man, who tells you the weather report, your upstairs neighbor Sugar Plumps, who tells you secrests and gives you tasks, and then there is the mailman, who we only meet towards the end. There are two more charecters in the game, but they are not as important for the story as the before mentiont.The analyzing part of this game, is that the fireplace could be a metaphor for gaming.Everytime the fireplace is mentiont the charecters keep taliknig about how you are just wasting time playing the game, not even in a bad way, but more in a revelatory way, where you can think about what you are doing. Sugar Plumps is also good to back of this theory, since she is talking about you two are so close, and yet so far, in relation to the fact that you are palying games together, but in the very end, you are only two screens looking at eachother, insteed of meeting in real life.If you would like a game, where you burn stuff in order to get money to burn more stuff, this is the game for you.If you are a person that like a simple stoyline you easily can interpretent on, this is a game for you.If you like to solve puzzeles, and get rewards in games, this is a game for you.I give this game a thumps up. 7 out of 10

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
Hey, Kids! Burn ALL Of Your Toys! - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]Hey, hey, kids! How are you doing today? Are you having fun? No? Are you bored of the internet? Cat pictures and♥♥♥♥♥♥not enough for you? All these electronics all over the place just white noise getting in the way of your fun? I have an idea!BURN IT ALL. EVERYTHING. HA HA HA. IT'LL BE TONS OF FUN. AND IT'LL KEEP YOU ALL NICE AND TOASTY-WARM. DO IT. BURN ALL OF YOUR TOYS. BURN IT ALL.Oh? You can't? Well, why the ♥♥♥♥ not? It's easy, come on, anyone can do it. Here, I'll even get you started. Here's your own little personal, nonstop, high-definition, entertainment fireplace. Little Inferno! (Uproarious screams of feral children)Little Inferno is the latest indie masterpiece from the geniuses behind World of Goo, over at Tomorrow Corporation. Originally a launch title for the Wii U's eShop, Little Inferno also found a nice home on PC and Mobile.Like its predecessor, Little Inferno is incredibly unique. The art style is noticeably distinct, with a strong Tim Burton vibe. And that style seems to leak into every other aspect of the game in all of the best ways. Your only purpose in the game is to burn everything. Burn it all. Let it all burn. If that doesn't sound like fun to you, why, you may as well be at the bottom of the ocean.Little Inferno will start you off with the meager instruction manual of the fireplace itself, which will burn pretty quick. But everything you burn will fade to dust, and from that dust will pop magical coins. Coins of a material far more valuable than gold, or silver. They're coins of love. Or maybe chocolate, but those would melt close to the fire.Once you've gotten that far, the entirety of the game opens up to you. You'll be able to purchase a fine selection of perfectly burnable items from one of the many catalogs. Each one brings with it its own unique properties. If you burn batteries, they explode. If you burn wood or paper, it burns very bright and quick. And if you burn living things, why they let out the most delightful scream. But it's not until you've started combining things that the action really starts to heat up. Ba-dum-tss.Little Inferno is a special game in that it's not one with concrete goals. There are no missions to complete, or collectibles to find. It's a simple game with a simple goal. Burning things. It's not quite a puzzle game, or a physics game, or a sandbox game. But it definitely features elements of all three.Trivial "combo" challenges work as one of the little things to keep you busy, tasking you with solving little pun riddles by burning specific items together. For example, the "Springtime" combo requiring you to set fire to a pack of flower seeds and an alarm clock. Which explodes into a fun little mess of flowers and mechanical bits. Aside from that, the only real "goals" to the game are burning every object at least once.But Little Inferno isn't one of those kinds of games. Little Inferno is about more that that. It's about bigger things. Simply burning everything, yeah, that's pretty fun. But the game's surprisingly strong story leaves the biggest impact. And it's done in such a subtle way. In addition to the many flammable objects that you'll be getting in your little mailbox, you'll get occasional letters from your neighbor and other characters. While at first innocent, charming, and mildly creepy, they'll slowly start to clue you in to a much bigger, much more chilling goings-on happening away from your fireplace.It's not a very long game. Unless you attempt to solve every challenge, you should be done with it in hours. It's a lot like like lighting your house on fire. It goes out super fast unless you pour gasoline on it. Trust me. You wouldn't even need to call any firefighters or anything. If you're looking for the kind of game that you can sink tons of time into doing things that might seem "productive", this game is not it. But the developers clearly put a lot of love into every little object. Each one is unique in quite a few ways. Some of them have multiple pieces, or react to fire in fun ways. And some have properties that can interact with other objects. You can light a cat on fire and have it explode, filling your entire fireplace with cat poop. And then drop a nuke inside. What kind of sick person would NOT jump at the opportunity to nuke a fireplace full of cat poop?Once you've burned through the game, Little Inferno's haunting and chilling feel will live on in your mind for quite a while. Everything from the zany pyromaniac action to the beautiful use of sound and music, and quirky art direction will leave an impression on you. It's definitely the kind of game that sticks with you for a while after. Burning inside you. Ba-dum-tss.It's the most fun you can have that isn't lighting actual things on fire. And once you've finished playing it, you can just burn the game too. Burn your computer, your game systems, your phones, just burn everything. It'll be tons of fun.Always remember, kids. If you're not the one setting things on fire, you're just the kindling.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Little Inferno is a really hard game to do a review on. Aside from being completely unique, everything is a potential spoiler and just a product of interpretation.I'll talk about its 2 parts. I'll start of with the actual game mechanics, and I'll then talk about the themes it adresses and how well they're complemented with its mechanics.In Little Inferno you have but one objective. And that is to burn stuff. And then, buy more stuff to burn. As you burn something, you'll get just enough money to buy something more.That's the premise. Regarding presentation, the game if fairly minimalist, but also very unique. The graphic style may remind you of World of Goo, and rightfully so, as it was made by the same designer.As you spend most of your time burning stuff, it's obvious that the fire effects would be the focus here. And they look absolutely amazing at times. Perhaps not the flames themselves, but the whole dynamic smoke created around it, with which the player can interact (while waiting for something to burn).Simple, yet awesome visuals.The music is just as simple, and also really good! It's usually more in the background, but it does fit the setting pretty well, and you can clearly hear it in the needed moments. So, all in all, great sound design!Now, the mechanics.In this game, when you buy a certain item, you need to wait for it to arrive to your home. This starts out by taking a couple of seconds, but grows to as much as 5 minutes in the end of the game.If you're out of money, there are also spiders and other bugs that appear in your fireplace from time to time, that drop a coin after you burn them.Do you get it now? Seems an awful lot like "cow-clicker", right? Well, to a certain point, it is. But it's also much more than that. More on that later.There are 2 types of currency. One, is just coins, that you can use to buy more items, or inventory slots. The other one, is Stamps, that you can use to speed up the delivery process (1 Stamp for 30 seconds). You can see it as the "Premium Currency" in most social games. But you don't pay for it, of course.How does one earn stamps? By making Combos, which is the main mechanic of the game (aside from mindlessly burning everything you can!). Not unlike iOS and social games, there are missions. Achievements (in-game only), if you will. On this tab, all you're given is the name of said Combo, and the number of items needed for it (ranging from 2 to 3).There are about 100 different combos, but you only need to do 45 of them to be able to "finish" the game.Some of them are pretty obvious, others are far harder. What impressed me here was that some of them require were far deeper than I expected them to be, even if presented in a very light way. Just like the rest of the game, actually. It can have fairly deep interpretations, or it can not. Everything is very casually presented, never pointing fingers or judging anything. Just making the player aware of its message without trying to force it into him. And it does it very well!The game is divided into catalogues, each with a theme, and items about it. The Combos can be about one single catalogue, or include items from different ones. Initially, you only need money to unlock catalogues, but later on, you'll need stars to be able to access them (stars can be acquired by completing combos).And that's mainly it, really. While you do all this, you'll receive letters from 3 people, but this fits more into the subjective nature of the game, and not as much to the mechanics, as a game.As a conclusion about gameplay only:It's a very limited game, and despite all the work put into the synergies between some of the items (and some were really, really good! I loved most of them), it's mostly flavour, and not a lot of meat. And that was intended, making it harder to criticize.Regardless, if you're looking for a challenging game, or a traditional game, stay away from this. It's not why it was made, and I doubt you would appreciate it if you went into it looking for that. This is mostly grind and no challenge in terms of gameplay.The game can be a bit boring and laborious at times and to be honest, I think it overextended a little bit. The points could have been made with less grind, but it's hard to say.So, why is it good?The game adresses themes related to the rise of social games, so called "cow-clickers", and how people waste their lives in front of the screen, doing nothing.The point of the game is to burn food, toys, statuettes, ... everything, really. Things with inherent value to them, and yet... you're just burning it all. The world is a cold, scary place outside, so you simply burn everything that can remind you of it. You don't think about why you're doing it, you simply do it. You and probably thousands of others. But you can't really be sure, you only know 3 people! As I said, the game isn't trying to criticize or make fun of anything, necessarily. It simply presents the subjects to the player, and never really opinates on it. It's all left to interpretation. It would have been easier to point fingers and laugh, but no. Little Inferno is classier than that.Another important aspect, is the context of the game. Right now, the closest connection might be casual games, but the same can apply for countless other situations, it's a pretty versatile metaphor.This game can lead to way more discussions that I can write about right now, and most of them would probably spoil the experience.I tried not to give away too much about it, but I'm not sure I've managed that very well.If you're looking for a completely different that will make you think, pick it up, it's really great! If you're looking for a challenge, don't do it. It's not the point of it and it will probably leave a really bad impression on you.Buyer beware: First off, the game doesn't make its point very clear very fast. It will test your patience before showing its cards, mostly in the ending.Second, the game was trying to burn my graphics card (how ironic, isn't it? I hope that was not intended haha!) due to a lack of V-Sync. You can however enable it directly in the settings documents. Go to user/.../AppData/Roaming/Little Inferno/settings.txt and change the option from 0 to 1, and save the file. That solved any issues for me.This was a really awesome experience overall. The path wasn't the most enjoyable, but the ending made the whole thing fit, and worthwhile.It's great to be surprised by small indie teams with titles like Little Inferno. Give this one a try!

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												It's a simple game, the videos on the store page will give you a good idea of what the gameplay is like - burn things in a fireplace. Expanding a little on that, the idea is that you burn stuff you buy from the games store in combinations which lets you get access to another level of things to burn. And you don't have to worry about running out of in game money to buy stuff from the store as everything you burn gives you money !Some of the stuff you can burn in your little inferno are really fun, some of the stand outs for me are the mini planets, the cold heart, the nuke, the chainsaw and the valkyrie woman among others.My one gripe is there are no options, running at 1000fps isn't really nessesary so a v-sync option would be nice. And the worst for me is no volume control, the inferno itself is rather quiet as you'd expect from a fireplace but when you go to the store to buy supplies the store music is too loud and repetetive this annoys everyone in my house, myself included!Those are just small complaints though, the game has a humerous and endearing story, fun gameplay and doesn't seem to have any technical faults unlike many other games being sold these days, beware though that for me it only lasted 7.5 hours until completion (I did have to cheat a bit looking up combo's to burn though).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I was holding off on getting this game because of the childish looking graphics, dialogue, and gameplay, but then I saw some YouTube lets-players play the game so I decided to get it for myself.  It was probably one of the best decisions of my life. This game is INCREDIBLY entertaining, as the wacky dialogue has you craving for more, and the crazy items you can get leave you stuck to the screen, trying to get the remaining combos for the next unlockable catalogue.  It is a short game, as I beat it in about 4 hours, but it does have a high replay value, due to the 99 combos you can get, and just the overall stress releaving attitude of the game.  I would say get this if you are into simple games, cause this game will have you craving the aspect of setting things on fire to release you of your pent up stress.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												If Tim Burton made video games, this is probably what he'd make.  It's artsy and metaphorical without being pretentious or obtuse.  The metaphors are pretty plain to see: You burn things to get money you can use to buy things you can then burn for more money... But it has to end sometime.  When shopping, it plays 50's era music to get you in the mindless consumerist mindset, to boot.  Most things don't simply burn.  When you burn sausages from the food catalogue, a swarm of flies bursts out, for example, or an ear of corn pops into popcorn.  This adds a little suspense and entertainment to what would otherwise be just a fireplace simulator.  To give the player something to actually think about, there are "unlockable combos" that really do nothing but give you something to complete.  (There are even exactly 100 of them to complete for 100% completion...)  These are mostly puns or "do you remember these items that share a similar theme from 10 minutes ago?"  I.E. "Polar Bear" requires you burn the South Pole and stuffed bear toys together.That said, not to cut into the dev's bread money, but you should probably buy this one on sale - It's not the sort of game that will last you more than a few hours unless you want to replay it or let your friends/family play a second game, and $10 for 2-5 hours of bemusement, especially when a lot of it ultimately amounts to filler, anyway, pushes my tolerance.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												What's not to like about this game? You burn things. Things that scream. There's a mystery here to be uncovered. Why are you sitting in front of your fireplace burning all your toys? Why are some of the catalog items you burn disturbingly...wrong? What's that strange thumping coming from the other side of the wall? You have to play to find out.Little Inferno is set in front of a fireplace. You order items from catalogues, and you burn them. There are combos of items, and it's up to you to puzzle out what they are, and burn the correct combinations, in order to progress. That's all. There's nothing more. If you need more, then I suggest you move along to another game. But if you're just the least bit tempted, pull up a chair next to the fire, and burn some things with me. It's warm here, next to the fire....

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												A surprisingly melancholy experience, Little Inferno is a captivating piece of interactive entertainment. I say that because it really isn't much of a game, at least not in the normal sense. There are no scores, no real goals to complete, and no enemies to fight. And yet it still manages to get under your skin and hook you from the minute you light your first toy on fire.But, burn, buy, burn, the endless and monotonous grind should be an absolute chore, but somehow I couldn't stop playing the game. Maybe it was the fantastic presentation, that is both charming and creepy do to the fact you are ultimately burning them all. Or maybe Little Inferno is trying to say something about the way games inherently snare us in away from the world, and the fact I was so drawn into it only further drives home this message.I can't honestly describe my experience with Little Inferno, and I'm not even sure I would say I enjoyed it, but what I do know is that it unlike anything else, and absolutely worth playing!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												5/10+ Great music score - cute, atmospheric, memorable. It is a bit repetitive though.+ There's a large range of items to burn, and they are nicely designed+ Physics are well done+ The game has a unique charm to it+ The story and style of the game is very different in the last part of the game, but is not intriguing enough to make the whole experience worthwhile.- Burning stuff gets old quick. - Gameplay is very limited. You basically burn items, and if you burn enough combinations of some items (combos) you move to the next level, only to find a catalog with a bunch of new items to burn.- Combos seem quite random. Some make sense, most do not.- Delays until items arrive is annoying, especially if you run out of "Tomorrow Stamps" (which are used to accelerate shipments)- You occasionally receive letters, but they're repetitive and not very interestingAll in all, a rather boring game that I can't recommend. If it's part of a bundle you may want to give it a shot, but I wouldn't spend much to buy it.

number of helpful: 49 of 97 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												To me Little Inferno is about as much fun as you can have with a fire. Five minutes of watching stuff burn and then you begin experimenting with other things and see how they burn away in to the flames. From a game point of view it's a very shallow amount of gameplay and even for a short game (depending on how fast you combine certan items to burn to fill a check list) it feels like it over stays it's welcome. The novelty of burning stuff wears off fast and once completing the game you are given what I'll expect is supposed to be a meaningful story covered in whimsy and a burton-esque theme but comes off as a desperate attempt at social commentary. Yes we get how destroying material objects in order to gain more is a look in to our own lives and how we live in society but it's not really adding to the entertainment of the game in question.I enjoyed Little Inferno for ten minutes. After that you are just going through the motions.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I really enjoyed this game. Pros: - The art style is very charming.- The soundtrack, though limited in diversity, is quite good.- Gameply is fun and addictive. Every item in the game reacts differently when burned. It's good incentive to progress through the game to see what the next unlocked item will be and how it will react when you torch it.- There is a story, and it's quite good. I loved the ending.Cons:- Some of the item combos were VERY difficult to figure out. I had to cheat and look them up a few times. After seeing what they were, I still couldn't see how anyone could have figured them out on their own.- It's a fairly short game.I had a lot of fun playing Little Inferno. A short but sweet experience I won't soon forget.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Personal Rating: 8/10This game. It's great! The story is simplistic, yet very effective, making you care for the characters in the game. If you want a burning simulator, this is for you. If you want a depressing story about the Tomorrow Corporation Owner leaving everyone for dead, this is for you. The art style, beautiful. The animations on each burning object, neat. The amount of time and thought that went into this game is superb.Now from that above statement you're probably thinking. "But Doc! Why isn't it 10/10?"Well, that's a very easy question. It reminds me of The Simpsons Tapped Out. Constantly waiting for another object, to move on to the next part of the story, that is spoon fed to you every ten minutes or so. Another thing is replay value. None that I can find myself doing, it's a one playthrough game, however fun it is. I must admit there are side "quests" that have been added, like finding all the recipies and the secret ending (which I wont be spoiling). In closure, it's a lovely game and it's worth the money to support the developers future depressing inferno games.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												It's a rather short game, I played through it in four hours, but I also skipped a lot of combos and such because I didn't see the point in doing it to get them starred, when the stars didn't earn you anything, and getting the combos doesn't unlock an achievement for Steam. I would love to see achievements or trading cards added, because I'm an achievement hound and I like trading cards/crafting badges, but even without those the game is worth playing. It's got a bit of a lesson to it, mostly one of those "Don't waste your life in front of a computer" lessons. I liked the humor in the game, I love the music in the game, and the art, sound effects, and visual effects are lovely. I definitely recommend this game, and I can totally see the irony in saying that. It's just a fun, casual game. Plus, you can burn pictures from your own files in the game, so it could be a little therapeutic when angry with a family member or best friend. Not that anyone would use that function for such purposes.....

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I was really pumped for this game considering people involved with "World Of Goo" created this. I bought it full retail on day 1. I was actually pretty disappointed. The game is most certainly fun, filled with lots of colorful explodey burny things, but it lacks direction. There is a challenge to unlock all of the hidden combinations you can make with the different toys, but isn't required to beat the game. If you want to set things on fire, watch the colorful explosions and laugh evilly at burning teddy bears... Then this is the game for you. I would suggest getting it on sale as it is only 6-8 hours gameplay at most with no replay.

												A surprisignly addictive game; I had previous bought this from humble bundle 8 and only recently had it brought to my attention by a friend to play.It has an amazing soundtrack, the physics and watching things burn is surprisingly addictive (in part due to not only the physics, but the way things burn up/crumble/special effects from certain things,) But looking even deeper into it, there's a story, and the story is quite compelling if you're paying attention to the letters you get, all the way up until the end. content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												This disturbing, yet cute little game hooked me hard. All you do is light things on fire, but there's so much more to it. It's so much funner than its simple concept and gameplay suggests it to be, if lighting things on fire sounds fun all by itself, just go get this game. It's just amazing. I got it on a sale for $4, and I got a simply lovely game experience. There is some kind of story that pushes you along as well, and the presentation is so top-notch that it really blows my mind that this game was made largely just by three people. Just a really great game, I was truly enthralled throughout the entire thing. And the burning is very satisfying, and there's just so many things to burn. Just go get the game and BURN BURN BURN EVERYTHING! It's great!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												I was pleasantly surprised by the actual depth of the story line, in what appeared to be a simple physics and fire puzzle type game.  The music is great, the atmosphere is spooky and single focused, and you develop attachments to characters you never even see.  The mechanism is simple, but the message is complex. All in all, I'm pleased that I bought the game, I enjoyed playing it, and forsee me buying it for friends in the future, because what's the point of having friends if you can't enable their inner pyromaniac, I ask you?  That said; I'm not sure the game has a tremendous amount of replay-ability, if you get all/most of the combos the first time through, because I don't think the emotional "punch" will be there if you know what's coming.  This is a beautifully done game, both visually and storytelling, and well worth the price.

												For Adults :This game is delightful, and if you burn through it in short order, you can experience a narrative with the tone of an early Tim Burton film. It is delightfully macabre, and in its final act - surprisingly affecting. Worth the 10 dollar price of admittance, and practically a steal when on sale. For Children:I can't even imagine how fun this game is for a kid. Seriously, my partner's siblings beg me to play this game. The harder combinations are pretty difficult for some kids under say 6 or 7, but as long as they can read - they can usually figure them out through experimentation.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Welcome my brothers , come in from the freezing cold into the world of Little InfernoThe first thing you should know, is that it's freezing, like really freezing, my nipples can cut diamonds freezing. As a functioning member of society, you the noble consumer order various pieces of illegal contraband from the Tomorrow Corporation, aka as the Guatemalan black market. The crafty people of Guatemala can get you all kinds of things, a bus full of children, a conveniently shrunken moon, and a nuclear device. Yes , you heard me right ! A NUCLEAR DEVICE. You can now be the envy of despots everywhere, well until you burn the device in a fireplace. Yes, you must sacrifice, time, money, and your own sanity as you burn away your already meager funds so you can line the pockets of rich fat cats in their ivory tower of doom overlooking your pitiful hovel. You shall spend countless hours in front of the fireplace, watching spiders burst into flame as the decadent pyre grows ever taller, threatening to overtake you. How can you, a mere man stand against such majesty, a child you yourself created ?! A man chooses, a slave obeys ! Rise young hero ! RISE AND TAKE UP THE SWORD OF DESTINY !

												The game itself is pretty neat, but it has a pay to win aesthetic which I found insurmountable.  The point of the game is to burn stuff in your fireplace, and sometimes burning specific stuff in conjunction.  There is also a girl next door who creates something of a plot.  This is all ok.  The problem was when you order stuff to burn, it takes longer and longer to show up.  This is akin to any mobile game which makes you pay to speed up the timer.  The timer is not part of the game, it is only an inconvenience.  That mechanic got SO annoying I cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This seemingly simple game just has so incredibly much style! It is really amazing. The main features of this game are fun enough, I mean, who doesn't like burning things? But the real charm is in the story. You start off by burning things, creating combo's and unlocking more things to burn, but after a while some odd things I won't go into detail about happen, and you start feeling like there's something wrong with burning things... But of coarse it's a ton of fun, so you keep doing it. More and more weird♥♥♥♥♥♥happens and... Ah hell, you'll have to experience it. Fun mechanics, great story, short gameplay. Definitely worth your time though, and about 5 bucks I'd say. Get this one, it's really great. One of the rare moody games, that sadly don't really get made anymore. Which is exactly why you should buy it. If you want. You have to.

The harder combinations are pretty difficult for some kids under say 6 or 7, but as long as they can read - they can usually figure them out through experimentation.

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Now, I was a huge fan of World of Goo which was created by the same team as Little Inferno, it has a charming characterization of goo and a Tim Burton-esque art style (I hate to always compare anything with a dark cartoon like style to Tim Burton but whatever). Not to go off on a tangent, but World of Goo was a great puzzle/engineering game, it was stylish, polished, sympathetic, and magical, I was totally enraptured by the whole experience.When I heard that they were making a new game I immediately became elated, I watched the teaser trailer for Little Inferno and was hooked. Constantly I wondered what the gameplay was going to be like. And then I heard the news… Little Inferno was little more than a simple app; a time waster, an “I have 5 minutes to kill so I’ll play this silly game” game. I felt defeated. I tossed away my hopes and moved on towards other titles.Then it just so happened that Little Inferno was in fact, in one of the Humble Indie Bundles, of course I bought it for Hotline Miami but hey, I might as well check out Little Inferno and form my own opinions. Well, I cannot say that it was not what I was expecting. It is a game where you burn stuff, yeah that is it. A game for pyromaniacs. Now there are quite a lot of things to burn, mind you, but the entire game is buy things from a catalog and toss them into your “Little Inferno” and burn, burn away.If you were ever a kid (and I am sure most of you were), then you may remember a point in your childhood wherein you took to the matches and lit stuff on fire, either army men, toys, sticks, etc… That is what this game is, it taps into your inner pyromaniac; watching the warm orange glow of a smoldering grandma; it all feels very comforting.Now, as you play, you will constantly unlock new things to burn, some things burn nicely, like stuffed animals or wood, and others not so much, like fragile china. It all feels very rewarding, in that, you purchase stuff to burn, and when you burn it you get more money for burning for which you can spend to purchase more stuff to burn; it is a vicious cycle. A very simple concept, yet it somehow is extremely hypnotic.I have not quite explained everything though, there is a slight puzzle element, where you need to burn a combination of items based off some keywords, for example: CORNFLAKES – you need to burn corn and a box of cereal. Some of the word puzzles are fairly simple, and others can be quite a stretch. These puzzles leave a bit of room for thinking while you wait for your products to arrive. Yeah, I don’t quite know why they incorporated a time period for items to be delivered to you other than to pad gameplay, but it becomes especially obnoxious once you have done everything in the game and must wait around a minute to get your items. You can use coupons to speed up the delivery but come on, I have ‘beaten’ the game, just let me burn stuff.And that about covers the entire game; Oh, I almost forgot, the story. Now, I will admit, that I did not quite understand the ending or even what the whole story was really about. This is what I gathered – global warming. Yeah, I really hope I am wrong about this, but the entire concept is that the world is getting colder and nobody knows why, so stay inside and burn all your toys. It is not that hard to see the correlation; but it is not like it really matters, they do not even expand upon this idea, it feels like there is about as much depth in the narrative as there is in the gameplay.Well, I think I have said all that there is to say about this one. Is worth your time? Not really. Is it cheap? No, in the same manner as Proteus, it is offered for an outrageous price of $10, two dollars seems more appropriate. I won’t complain since I got it in the bundle, but you should avoid paying full price. Overall, it is a cozy and entrancing little game yet too shallow to really offer an experience.So no I cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Brutally simple as it is, it is a great game. Little Inferno is a bit of a parody on consumer society and the entire product placement industry. You order products and you burn them, while corresponding via letters with different kinds of characters. It is much more interesting than it sounds, though. Almost every object you burn has its character and has its own weird physics and if you combine them properly, you get combo bonuses (in fact, you could say that that's your main in-game task). As the game itself states, mockingly self-conscious, there are no timers, level grinding and failures, mere incinerating with casual, but addictive, puzzle solving. In fact, if there was a genre called "sadistic pyro puzzle", this would be it.Even though I got this from Humble Bundle, I would say that it is worth its standalone price.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												A good game that's about watching high-definition pixels burning all the things while being very amusing and relaxing.Little Inferno is a causal, relaxing game with a underlying message behind the gameplay and the story that's told through mail you get periodically every now and again when you buy the next tier of items to set ablaze in your Little Inferno Playset.Before I explain the gameplay, I want to explain some of the foundations of this game this way it feels less awkward in the transistion to the mechanics and how this game is played.So to start. Little Inferno takes place in a time where the world is on apocolyptic-conditions due to the fact that the weather outside is in artic-conditions. Little Coporporation invented "The Little Inferno" to stall the arctic advances with creating a temporary source of heat emitted from the Little Inferno playsets (there's many theories and spoilers surrounding this subject, so i'll avoid that.). You have been given one of these playsets in-regards to your entertainment of setting a vast assortment of items on fire.Okay, in this game there's three main characters as you progress. The Weatherman who gives you up-to-date messages about the world and weather, Bubbles, who is your neighbor and also possess a Little Inferno Playset. And then there's the CEO of Little Inferno Corporation who sends you letters from time to time.To progress the story, you have to buy items to burn and then harvest the coins that drop from said burned items to purchase a more-expensive item. You continue doing this until you reach the end of a catalouge. Then you'll be given the option to buy the next catalouge, which has a fee requirement and a combo requirement.Combos, are essentially puzzles. You get a list of these said "combos" with a combo title and a clue to how many items are needed to achieve it.  To do this, you must figure out what items are involved in the combo and then you must buy them and then burn them altogther sharing the same flame. If the combo is correct, it will be checked off on your list and you'll be given stamps.Stamps, are used to fast-forward the time you have to wait for shipments to come to your home in the game. The longer amount of time it takes to get there, the more stamps it will cost. Essentially you can wait the time down to be something you'd be more comfortable spending. So say an item costs 7 stamps to instantly send it to your inventory, you can wait a minute or two and then have it sent directly to your house at the price of 3 stamps.Stamps are just used for when you're feeling a little impatient and want to speed things up. They are dropped randomly from a burned item from time to time.The game has good pacing as buying a new catalouge eats up a hearty wad of your cash. More or less forcing you to start from one or two catalouges in the past and work your way back up again. But it also gives you opportunity to figure out other combos as some combos cannot be completed until a new catalouge and item is unlocked.The special effects and sound effects in this game are quite good. There's high-definition effects mixed in with their art style and they work well with each other. Also this games good sense of dark humor is quite pleasing.I found it hard to find any issues with this game as any issues I have with it stems with the fact that I may have not been playing it relaxingly and casually. This game functions very well and it's items mechanics are quite good, no bugs, glitches or anything. Everything functions smoother than a hot blade through butter. It was a very good experience.The story behind the gameplay was very solid, and the games mechanics are simple but they're perfect and well-designed for a relaxing casual game like this.So, all in all. The sound effects are good and they make the proper sounds for all interactions I feel. The balance between the art-style and the graphics they used is well-done. The humor's good, the story's good. I can't complain about this game. At all. They know what they envisioned, and they made it and really made a perfectly functioning game and I commend them for that. Nothing seemed out of placed or a nail jagged out of the floorboards if you catch my drift.I have replayed Little Inferno 3 times, I am unsure of how many times people would replay this game. So I can't give a reasonable estimate for that other than you'll surely beat it once. I bought this game on sale, but it is most definitely worth the full price.Thank you for reading my review, I hope it has aided you in your consideration if you want to buy this product or not.Just know that even if you beat this game once and you wouldn't want to beat it again. ...you'll definitely return to just watch things burn in all their high-resoluted burning glory.Again, thanks for reading. Have a good one.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Little Inferno is a game about letting go of the past.Like the writings of Aesop, Little Inferno could be described as an allegorical narrative. From the outset of the game, we learn that nothing matters, except for its capacity to burn. Even the rules of the game are among the first things that are incinerated. From there, nothing is spared from the fire. Photographs, cardboard hearts and letters, everything that could be considered sentimental is burned, destroyed, and forgotten. This is a sentiment that I can personally relate to.Modern consumerism is also explored, and perhaps, one could argue, taken to its logical conclusion. Meaningless things are bought and burned to make way for more meaningless things. This is a cycle that can continue indefinitely, and unless you choose otherwise, probably will. It is a stark warning, but in this warning is also a kind of comfort.In conclusion, there is much to discover in the modern computer game Little Inferno. It is a whimsical adventure that hides a serious side, and after extensive exploration I am left with one, final regret. It is a regret that I cannot throw my life onto a fire in the way that is depicted in this game. All I can do is take an overdose of sleeping pills and strike one final match, letting it fall into the strategically placed pools of gasoline spread around the house. This will be my final act. Goodbye.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												21/30 Gameplay	10/12 Replayability 12/12 Sound 14/17 Graphics	12/12 Controls	12/17 Longness	81/100In "Little Inferno" you...well...burn stuff. That's it. And for some reason burning stuff gives you money- more than you have to give out for buying them items. So... well... boring you think? No!There are 100 Combos you can breake, some are more hard, some less, and having enough combos you unlock new items. So you always have a motivation for finding out the combos. But anyways...it becomes repetetive after some time and so the game left some points back at gameplay.But it is pretty nice for Replayability: Sometimes I just think: "Hmm, how about buring some stuff and have a nice fire" and open it. Just for the heck of it. I burn, because I burn. As the human is, because he is. There is no really deeper sense- wait! THERE IS!This video game makes you think about your whole lifestyle... You have these crazy characters...And KEEP THE COUPON UNTIL THE END!... and then this ending- well, I ain't spoiler. But if you become sick of the game just watch it on youtube- it is really worth it.Sounds and Graphics are neat as every item has his own animation and sound effects and it is just fun to see and hear it. The music is where you need them and characterizing the game, but not nerves you off when you want a nice fire. Everything nice done, Tomorrow Cooperation!Controls cannot be easier- click to burn. That's it. Just the Longness of the game is not sooo long (ca. 4-5 hours for "plot"), but as it was in a Humble Bundle that is quite enjoyable. I mean- if you want more you get more! So...pretty nice, but not perfect.TL;DR: I think Little Inferno is a fun game to play, has middle-high points in all categories, be sure to check it out! Just test it and love it...or not...and think about the plot when you are done!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Little Inferno is a quirky little game for the most casual of gamers. The game consists of the player receiving various catalogues of items that the player must then set fire to. While that in itself might seem redundant, there is actually a stategy to your pyromancy, where you need to figure out different combinations of items to burn to unlock various achievements. The fact that you are kept in front of a tiny fireplace during the game is kept fresh by the letters you receive, giving you small glimpses of the outside world. While the game is quite humorous, as you get closer to the end and the answers to why you are being made to burn these objects, the game starts to take a bit of a darker turn. All in all, the game is quite a joy to play, and anyone who likes a puzzler as much as I do, is in for a treat.

												This was a great little indie game. If you're a huge pyromaniac (like me) you'll love it. The fire physics are great and there are so many things to burn! And underneath that shallow game mechanic is a very deep, ironic metaphor that the game slowly unfolds to you. This game offers a cheerful, creepy, and entertaining experience that really makes you think about your life. 8/10

												This is a great indie game made by the people who brought you World of Goo, it is a game based almost exclusively in front of a fireplace.You sit in front of a fireplace and collect coins to buy stuff that you can burn, in the shop, which you burn to get more coins, etc.As you burn your way through there is storyline progression from an interesting and bleak world.You may also progress through cryptic achievements throughout the game.This game is simple and intriguing, it hasn't got too much wrong with it apart from lack of replayability and the quietness of the game (although intestinal to add to bleak atmosphere) and it also hasn't got the most exiting gameplay.9/15 "Burn things"
