content:
Posted: June 25, 2013
												Little Inferno is a physics sandbox.  The user chooses objects, puts them into the box, moves them around, and burns them.  Each object is some kind of very dark joke, from the food items who sprout faces and scream when burned, to the highly explosive bottle of wine labeled "Midlife Crisis Mitigator" to the a cat stuffed toy who explosively launches turds on ignition.  The flames and explosions are beautifully rendered and physically simulated.There is a vaguely steampunk post-apocalyptic aesthetic (think Delicatessen), seamlessly blended into a critique on the state of modern casual games.  One spoiler: despite the armchair philosophy remeniscent of Fight Club, their is no twist.  But it mind♥♥♥♥s you regardless, all while being very coherent.Also, could someone tell me what happens if you don't burn the coupon for one free hug which you get towards the beginning?

												Interesting, but I found myself grinding for achievments. And then I realized the whole game is about grinding for achievement. You throw stuff into the fire. Posted: April 1, 2014
												Only on a sale. But at the same time extremely gratifying to burn catalogs of items and see how they interact as they burn, its like a boy scouts guide to being a pyro. but still not a complete game in the sense to pay full price for it. no way to loose, the story to me is pretty flat, and it basically comes down to just waiting for stuff to arrive in the mail so that you can burn it get money and then buy more stuff. But the FX are really good for the fire, and there are so many scripted items that the game is really enjoyable, I think its better suited for a tablet than playing on a desktop, but I got both in a bundle so I'm happy.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Little Inferno is a game about exactly that, a little inferno. Inside that inferno you burn things. Those things you must buy, but no worries, you get more money out of them than you pay for 'em. Rather odd, I know. So anyways, you buy those things from a catalog and burn them brutally (not really) and then repeat the same steps. But there are also combos that you must find in order to unlock the next catalog. They make the game a lot more interesting as you only have the name of the combo which is basically the only hint you get. The combos reward you with stamps that you use to get the stuff delivered to you faster if you are impatient.The gameplay itself is rather fun due to the a bit humorous descriptions of the items on the catalogs and due to the items themselves (and of course due to fire). Sometimes they're something simple, like a spoon or a brick, but sometimes they're something very very special, like a credit card or a TV! Awesome, I know. And they actually are a lot more interesting. They aren't the only not-that-ordinary items, there are plenty of them to keep the game interesting, and it does it successfully.Lil' Sucky Gameplay to go with the review.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												The concept of burning things in a fireplace is so simple, yet, in a simplistic but incredibly deep way, there's so much more to the game. The story is open to interpretation and the game ends up feeling like a metaphor. It’s short but great fun while it lasts, it keeps you going, wondering what you’ll discover next. The soundtrack is amazing, the kind whose simplicity but pure emotional tone can reach your soul. Perhaps emotional would be the best way to describe my experience with this game. I highly suggest trying this game, it’s well worth the price.

 TL;DR: ♥♥♥♥ING BUY THIS GAME!!!! 5th favorite game of all time, Great Mechanics, Beautiful art design, One of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in a game, and all made by 3 guys. 												This is a great indie game made by the people who brought you World of Goo, it is a game based almost exclusively in front of a fireplace.You sit in front of a fireplace and collect coins to buy stuff that you can burn, in the shop, which you burn to get more coins, etc.As you burn your way through there is storyline progression from an interesting and bleak world.You may also progress through cryptic achievements throughout the game.This game is simple and intriguing, it hasn't got too much wrong with it apart from lack of replayability and the quietness of the game (although intestinal to add to bleak atmosphere) and it also hasn't got the most exiting gameplay.9/15 "Burn things"

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												From the team that brought us World of Goo (One of my all time favourite indie games) comes Little Inferno.GameplayA simple drag and drop system where you buy new items from a catalog to successful complete combos and earn more money. It’s a nice little loop. It has a similar art style to that of World of Goo and features some really fun little animations that are tailors to the different items you can use.Top Tip #001Make sure to burn at least one of each item in the catalog. We’ve been doing this as we unlock another one because it makes it easier in the long run plus you get to see all the little fun animations as different things burn up. The second reason for doing this is you’ll find out which items like to explode on their own and which need a little extra to get them started.Upgrades and ProgressionThere are various ways in this game to progress and upgrade. One of the many ways is using the money you’ve earned in the form of buying new catalogs and extra spaces in your mailbox. The game keeps you aiming for it’s tasks so you’ll have to keep on top of all them combos too if you wanna keep unlocking new stuff.Top Tip #002Running low on money after making some bad combos? Track down them pesky spiders as they give you 3 corns and after collecting a couple of them you’ll be back to no good burning things again.Speed UpUsing the ‘Tomorrow Stamps’ you can speed up your purchases but we wouldn’t advise this certainly in the early stages of the game because it’s got a good progression speed that keeps in fun and entertaining even whilst you wait for your extra items. We were able to complete the game without using any of these at all so if you are willing to put in the time then try and match us on that.Top Tip #003The max money you can hold is 999 and the max ‘Tomorrow Stamps’ you can hold is 99, any more you collect after that won’t count so if your coming close why not take a minute from completing objectives and just burn some of your favourite in-game items.Mail TasksAs well as completing combos you also have to buy items for the odd little people that like to send you letters.Our favourite in-game itemsWe didn’t want to spoil the game too much so we’ve picked our favourites from the early sets of items you get, but later on there are some really entertaining onesMini Nuke – This sure packs a punch with a huge explosion.Mini Moon – This item has its own gravity similar to the moon and allows you to float all your items in mid airPublished Blog Post[www.dabs.com]

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Little Inferno is certainly a unique game. From beginning to end, you only have two interactive screens - the fireplace and the shopping catalog, as well as two actions - placing newly purchased things in the fireplace and burning them.Unfortunately, the latter somewhat limits the former, as, if you hoped for an interesting sandbox where you watch elaborate structures collapse and crumble, Little Inferno is not it: too much time is spent waiting for things to arrive, restocking, collecting money for the next purchase, not enough things that can qualify as building blocks in the first place, and the physics are somewhat cartoonish. Rather, the sandbox part of the game is reduced to placing items one by one in the fireplace and watching them burn. Or freeze. Or other neat stuff like that. Unfortunately, a huge number of avaliable items qualify simply as fuel, and novelty wears off somewhat quickly, too quickly to qualify as cathartic.Really, the actual game is a puzzle rather than a sandbox: you are offered a list of 99 combos of two or three items that can be burned together. There's usually no interesting gameplay interaction between these two or three specific items, which is rather disappointing, instead these items are related to each other by a provided clue (for example, the LOLcat combo consists of a cat plushie and a camera). Some of the clues are obvious and some are downright cryptic. You know inventory puzzles in point and click adventures? You, the heroic kleptomaniac, accumulate a number of random items and use one on another? Little Inferno is this as an entire game, except you have to wait before items arrive or use coupons for instant shipping that are in limited supply, and sometimes the items are annoying to combo burn properly.There's also a story unlocked as you progress through the game through a series of letters, it is, much like the actual game, kinda unique but nothing to write home about.I have acquired this game in a bundle and beaten it in about two hours, but for the price avaliable in the shop, or even at a standard discount, I cannot recommend this game to be purchased by anyone.5/10

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												How on earth can a creative little toy such as Little Inferno be so linear? While "playing" this game you feel like you are just burning things to unlock the rest of the things so that you can throw away this monstrosity, because Little Inferno is awful. It could have actually done rather well if the unlocking system was sorted out, but since there are so many restrictions on what you can burn and when you can burn them, it’s a losing battle trying to have fun with the toy. You start the game with a catalogue and only the first few objects are available for purchase. You get coins from burnt objects and every object coughs up more money than it was bought for. After you burn these items to a crisp, you go back to the catalogue and buy the next few items. Another problem the game has is that the objects that you buy from the catalogue don’t appear on your shelf immediately. Instead you have to wait for the objects to ship to your house, like freakin’ Amazon. If you really can’t wait, you can use a stamp (which is basically a rarer version of a coin) to knock 30 seconds off the delivery time. That’s right you can get a faster delivery. Like freakin’ Amazon. What makes matters worse is that there are seven catalogues and each one has items with longer and longer wait times for delivery until the last item which takes an outrageous five minutes to arrive.The only actual gameplay involved is making combos, which is where you are given a clue, then have to work out which two objects to burn together to complete the challenge. The only problem is, the clues are unbelievably obvious, for example “Bike-Pirate” is the clue for the combo involving the bicycle and the pirate. What fun.The developers even added a storyline in the form of very burnable letters from people you never actually meet. Almost every single one has the phrase “This can’t last forever” in some shape or form, and this could be like a side-plot except I don’t care in the slightest. I was put in mind of FarmVille and all those other Facebook games that spanned out their gameplay by having users spending most of the time waiting. I can only assume that these games were the developers’ only points of reference when designing. I know I’m probably being a little harsh since it’s only an indie game made by a tiny team of people, but if we can produce something as illuminating as Bastion, there is no need for Little Inferno hiding in a mass of smoke, getting in people’s eyes and making them water.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Gameplay 1/10:No failure states, no success states, the gameplay is just the vessel upon which the player's boredom rides to reach the auteurs' conclusion.Plot 3/10:Told through letters, and some exposition in the end, it's essentially irrelevant to the experience. One could argue that there are two stories being told: the story of the main character, told via traditional means, and the story of the player, told by the timers on the boxes as they're being stared at by pairs of eyes round the world, eager to discover the next nothing. Finally, there's no closure given, instead the player returns to the start screen, able to pick up from where they left.Character 5/10:Ms. Plumps is a classic example of a hamartanousa heroine, who, after being punished, distances herself from the tragic hero, who keeps committing the same crime till the ultimate hubris that will set him free, as it did her. However, none of the characters seems to have any more depth than their cardboard representations: Plumps is the ditz the PC should strive to follow, PC is a blank slate, Weather Man is stuck in his balloon, and Nancy is just someone with a plan that came to fruition regardless of any actions or omission by any other character.Thought 2/10:Only there as background noise, seeing as all the characters are single-minded pyromaniacs.Diction 5/10:It's what could have saved this game alone, if it was given a little more love. The message is simple, yet powerful. Any gamer has probably felt it (more so any critic/reviewer), however a simple mention of a deep thought is not the same as exploration of the same. In the end it felt like a cheap cop-out.Melody 6/10:The music has the decency to not overburden us with its presence.Spectacle 7/10:It manages to be pretty throughout; be it through sleek flammable objects, or haunting character design later on.Final verdict:Recommended only if you are willing to suffer mild boredom so that you can appreciate its half-baked message.

												Here's basically how you play this game.You figure out that you can burn everything.You burn the Terms and Conditions.You get REALLY excited.You unlock the catalog.You can even more excited.You're thinking, "this is the greatest game ever!"You burn everything in the first page of the catalog.You say to yourself, "I wonder what page two has to offer!"You burn everything in page two.So on and on and on. content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Little Inferno's actual gameplay leaves a lot to be desired, which is why it isn't a game most players will be returning to. With its short completion time, the game itself serves as a vehicle for its overarching message. Unfortunately, the game relies too heavily on its one-note atmosphere and handles its theme in a heavy-handy manner that ultimately insults its player--both literally and intellectually. The 'point' is hammered so obnoxiously and self-righteously, that the masochism that is playing Little Inferno attributes any negativity towards the game as being a part of its design. Unless you'd like a lesson in what a masturbatory game looks like, take a rain check on Little Inferno.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10
												Wow, this game is horrible. World of Goo was incredible, so i decided to try some more by the same guy, but this was just a waste of money. It's got good reviews... idk, maybe there was some artsy element that I missed, but I was just but I was just bored. So you start off with a tiny stash of cash and a small collection of toys you can order. You order stuff and it appears after a delay, and then you toss it in the fireplace and burn it, which always gives you a few more coins than you spent. Symbolism for the insatiability hunger of human consumerism maybe? Idk, but it got old in a hurry. Most of the toys react in some novel way as you burn them... the dragon breaths fire, the ear of corn has popcorn pop off of it, the moon changes gravity so things orbit it. I imagine you could make some tiny rube-golberg machines if you were so inclined, but the space is so limited that it's pretty limited so I didn't have much success. Also there are hidden combos of items. If you burn certain items together, you've completed the combo. Once you've got enough, you unlock new toys to burn. So a big part of the game is looking at the titles of combos and trying to guess which toys are required, which is easy when you've only got access to a dozen items, but once it's closer to 100 it starts to take some trial and error. A message about sitting in the same place, looking at the same thing, and still searching for novelty? Might be a meta commentary about spending too much time on a computer looking for interesting games, but that might be something I'm superimposing on the subject. There's a thin plot about a relation with the girl next door. You get letters, and exchange toys with her. She's fascinated by a mystery of the inferno. And the environment of the game, the whispers of the world outside the inferno are quite haunting. But, that was the only interesting part of the game that I could see, but there wasn't much of it. Anyway, eventually you hit on a mystic combination of items and burn the house down, and then you've got to find something else to do. The end. I usually enjoy artsy games and games with social commentary. World of Goo kept surprising me with understanded but poignant imagery. Little inferno though? No so much. I unlocked all the items and completed the endgame, in about 3 hour, which was much shorter than I like to see a $10 game take. Maybe there was symbolism I missed, but this was just a waste of time and money as far as I could see.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Ok, i really don't get all the praises this game get.You're burning stuff in the fireplace...some find it relaxing, i just find it boring. I like playing with fire, but i don't get that vibe out of Little Inferno, since it's mostly about waiting for new items to arrive, then they burn in a few seconds. Yet, I would write that down as personal preferences, and move on.But after that, it keeps getting worse. The wait timer become higher and higher, the money you need keep getting higher. So there is even less burning and a lot more waiting than before. Even at the end of the games, you will not get to do that much of a fire because "express delivery coupons" are so damn rare.I at least expected some kind of payoff when you "finished" the game, something that would raise it past the boring waiting mechanic...Well there is an ending...and it was almost as boring as the rest. Big disappointment. I wouldn't even recommend it on sale, whatever the price, it's not worth it.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												**I LIKE THIS GAME, BUT THERE ARE GLARING ISSUES THAT SHOULDN'T BE IN A PC GAME THAT COSTS MONEY**It's Little Inferno just for me. Now, the question comes in here: Is it really for me?I'll making this review into a quickie. LI is a fireplace simulator about consumerism and a very overused global issue that you'll find out about later in the game.The visuals are truly beautiful, the atmosphere is slightly claustrophobic, but in a good way, like the feeling of cuddling up under a thick blanket in a cold night in just the right way.The story is passable and most people won't really care about the "companion" or the other characters there. The writing is annoying if anything to be honest.Now, the products that you burn will have an interesting way of burning up at least 50% of the time. But here comes the real issue. You can order a limited amount of items, you have a limited sized wallet and you have to wait until you can buy the item again and the times can span up to 30 minutes, which is insane. There are skip tickets, but even then, it's ridiculous. Do I recommend this game? Sure, but make sure that it's heavily discounted or in a bundle. For a full price you'll be disappointed in it.

												This is a favourite of my 8 year old nephew. On a basic level you simply burn stuff, then once you get past that novelty you can start completing levels by burning the right items together to make 'combos'. Maybe my nephew will tell me all about it one day.A very polished, quality game with great graphics but perhaps not aimed at adults.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This does not mean I did not enjoy the game- I greatly enjoyed it. But I cannot recommend this game to anyone I do not know: It is a very specific taste of game.This will not appeal to the average gamer. If you are looking for depth, you may enjoy it. If you are looking for a great gameplay experience, you likely won't. If you just want to burn everything, you'll love it. The gameplay is built around repetition and waiting, as a satire of AVGM and the pay-to-win formula used in Facebook games. But this means that the game is designed to be repetitive: Not a great trait in most games. And if you don't like waiting five minutes to burn a single thing, it'll cost you stamps, which are an in-game currency you slowly accumulate.The entire game takes place in front of a fireplace, with the exception of the end, which serves to teach a preachy lesson about wasted time. But there is more to it than that, if you're willing to look into it. The depth is a decent hook for game analysts, and the meaning of the ending is vague enough to be interpreted as a good number of things, all positive and optimistic. Most people won't look into this, though, and I don't blame them.The atmosphere is just as fantastic and eerie as World of Goo was (Same creator), with that silver lining lingering in the distance. The dialogue is kooky and fun, yet reveals a dark and sinister motive. But I expect most gamers' reactions to this would be "so what?" Atmosphere does not make the game. It cannot serve as the initial hook, and only becomes tangible when the player is immersed.So no, I don't recommend it. It has fantastic atmosphere. It has a dark theme. It has a sweet-but-simple ending. It has great idle gameplay. But you would need to be an "artistic" gamer to acknowledge most of this. If you don't look for atmosphere in games, you won't care about it in this one. If you play games to play games, this falls short of the criteria.However, my negative rating of this will likely draw people that are honestly researching into if they should get this game. And, as you read through my review, you may notice that I am not describing you. You may think "I'm not an average gamer. These assumptions don't apply to me." If that's the case, then enjoy Little Inferno, as I have.

Posted: August 16, 2014
												A truly inspiring game and with a great sound track.  Join your character as he burns his toys in his Little Inferno: Entertainment system ™ from the included catalogs. Though after burning his toys he soon meets a friend named Sugar Plums. Over time they become great friends, but Sugar Plums’ curiosity drives her to discovering what lies out in life. You though do not. Though as you continue burning your toys and unlocking combos you fall into quite a predicament and use four special objects that you at first ignored or thought nothing of them  and realize what Sugar Plums was talking about. Now with you on your own, you go on to discover the world.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Little Inferno is basically a fire simulator. You set things on fire and they react in cool and funny ways. Seeing how each item would react to fire and how they would interact with each other is really fun, but the game has one major problem. Delivery times. Now I know that the required wait times are there as a sort of satirical comment leading to the game's ultimate purpose, but honestly it takes the fun out of the game. It just seems like it was put there to prolong the game because the developer's were worried about the amount of content. I think even if they kept the timing system there should be a way to reduce the time like if gold items actually had no shipping time instead of just no cooldown. Its annoying to have to wait 2 minutes everytime you want to get an item. Exploring each catalouge and seeing the interactions is really fun, but the need to wait for every item really makes me wonder if it is worth it.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Playing with real fires is way more fun.I only played 88 minutes. Won't finish game.  You burn things in combinations.  Does look cool visually, but I only kept going because I was thinking maybe there's more to it - as if the burning stuff was an intro game and the real game would start soon.  But apparently not much else happens. A big part of game seems to be to figure out what items to burn together to complete a checklist.  I greatly enjoyed the developer's previous game World of Goo, and that's the reason I tried this.  But it's just dull and pointless   I gather from other reviews (and did get the same sense while playing) that there's cultural commentary about burning things to make money to buy more things to burn, all the while spewing pollution up the chimney.  I get it.  But not very fun game.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												The premise of just throwing stuff into a fireplace to light it on fire doesn't really sound like a great game.  Throw in a few puzzles and now you've got something, but still not quite something great.  The sole point of this game is too find combinations of two or three items that fit a description on the list of combos.  For example, the Bike Pirate combo obviously needs you to burn the Bike and the Pirate, but others are not quite so easy.This is basically the game of Doodle God, but instead of unlocking new elements, you're just unlocking new junk to burn.  The game is moderately enjoyable at first, but the combo-finding rapidly loses its interest.  You also need to burn the same items over and over again just to grind and unlock the next catalogue of items, which further adds to the lack of enjoyment. The included dialogue with your neighbor does add a little bit of flare to the game, but not enough to make the game worthwhile.  There are far more games that you could be playing instead, so I wouldn't recommend wasting your time with this (unless you absolutely loved Doodle God).

content:
Posted: March 18, 2013
												Little Inferno is one of the hidden gems that doesnt get alot of recognition it deserves. This game doesnt have a goal that you need to achieve all you do is burn stuff you buy from a catalog, The concept is so simple it works perfectly for this game. It also haves a lot of humor that works and sometimes is Laugh out loud funny.The game has a story thats told throught some creppy but funny letters and it develops perfectly till the end.The burning mechanic is amazing and its amusing to watch all the stuff you burn turn to ashes and sometimes explode. This game has a puzzle system called combos. Combos are a mix of stuff you burn together to get stars and it works perfectly. This game is really fun and should be checkd out by everyone i give it a 8/10

												little inferno is an experience that as a kid i was obsessed with. after seeing many of the older day popular youtube channels play it and finding a pirated copy myself i begin to very much enjoy the game.Little inferno delivers a fun enviroment with some rather simple mechanics to any pyro maniacs and arsonists to be by giving you a rather simplistic story and a neverending supply of burnable materials via the catelog, it promotes creativity in the fire place by mixing and matching different flamable objects and has a colourful cast of characters that entertain along your journey through the Little Inferno Entertainment Fire Place.the game opens with you burning the instructions and saftey manual.i can fully recomend this game to anyone who is a fan of original ideas. fun mechanics. and indie games in general. the miniscule price tag makes it a rather fun game and it can get extremely addicting.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Incredibly. Disappointing. I did NOT finish the game, nor will I ever bother with it again. Do NOT waste your money (although apparently that is the stupid, ironic point of the game?).I really do not understand people in today's society who swarm over things with cheeky, hidden messages, as if they are some sort of saving grace for something that is terrible. You know, create some horribly bad game or TV show, but if it has a "fancy" meaning between-the-lines, then it is suddenly the best thing ever.This game is not a game. I played it first and foremost because the photos and videos looked like it would be a funny little way to spend some time, mixing the toys and things together to do silly things, like the moon's gravity, or trying to buy enough blocks to make a little castle and then burn it down or drop something on it.And it was enjoyable in that way for a little while. But once the game started drastically delaying all of the toys when you bought them, I became very bored and annoyed very quickly. Taking away some time for me sitting with the game idle and chatting with a friend, I probably played the game less than 90 minutes. Apparently the average players go to like 5 hours to finish the game, because they have to finish burning items in these combos and so on?And once they finish the game, as I looked into it after I shut it off and decided not to go further, they're basically given a message (although I could see parts of it showing up already, after-the-fact) that they are wasting their time doing some stupid repetitive mess like playing iOS/Android games that are just collecting some dumb items and making coins.Okay... Except 1) This isn't really that game market; and 2) I realized the game was stupid, so I didn't even get near that point nor does it apply. So basically I wasted money on a game that looked really silly and fun, but only was fun for less than an hour. Everyone somewhat raves about the game, which made me feel safer in making the purchase, and often I'm skeptical about user judgment... and would have been right to be so here.People praise this game saying that it breaks out of its mold and is great with its message of "dreams" and "living life." Some people even compare it to games like Spec Ops (saying how Spec Ops is a dark and anti-fun shooting game). Now, I loved Spec Ops (I played it on Xbox first) and agree it's dark and has a great story, but I don't understand people claiming this game to fit with that. This game is nowhere near the same thing. Spec Ops has a general message about life and war, and so does many books, movies, documentaries, etc. It's not exactly a "new" message. If people think it is, that is mostly because they're young and simply don't understand life or the repercussions of things like war. Blowing people up in games is fun if you disconnect your mind from it, and it is easier in something like Halo. But in "real" war scenarios, it is harder.Anyway, I am off-track talking about Spec Ops somewhat, but the point is that this game is just a waste to take your money, but not in the same way as those dumb mobile games. There really isn't a saving grace here to be found. There is no good "message" or point.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2013
												Just awful. Since the game description doesn't tell you anything useful, here's what the game is really about:You're given a list of achievement names, and the object of the game is to guess which combination of 2 or three objects you can select to get the achievement. This is extremely easy since the achievement names are usually a pun based on the object names. The whole deal with the fireplace and burning stuff is just a gimmicky way of doing multi-select. There is a completely pointless timer that you need to wait for between selecting each set of objects and essentially nothing to do while you wait for the timer, in the stupidest possible effort to pad out gameplay.If this game sounds original and different, it is. There's a very good reason why nobody's ever made a game like this before: it doesn't work on any level.

content:
Posted: March 10
												Little Inferno is a great casual game with just enough goal-oriented tasks to keep you playing through to obtain every achievement.Gameplay is simple enough for very young children to understand (my 3-year-old loves it) yet has enough built-in challenges that it kept me interested until the very end. Buying items from catalogs to gloriously burn in a home fireplace seems rather arbitrary, and it is, but it is also surprisingly entertaining. The story seems a little forced at times, with some rather odd elements throughout, but the payoff is rather interesting, as the game suddenly takes on a completely different feel, morphing seemlessly from one genre to another to see the game's conclusion.Bottom line: If you've ever felt the urge to set fire to everything in sight, Little Inferno will provide you with hours of digital pyro-tainment (which means that you won't get burned, or incarcerated, while indulging your pyromaniac tendencies).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Little Inferno is an outstanding work of interactive art. Initially, I thought it was a typical casual game: a few basic functions and some other components revolving around it, with little else than those functions as assets to the game. However, this game crushed my expectations. The basic functions (i.e. purchasing, receiving, and burning an assortment of items) were exactly as expected, from how it progressed to what you could get (though many items produced cool effects), but Little Inferno expanded far beyond the basic functions. The narration of the game--something I didn't believe existed--is mostly played through the main character's correspondence with another character by letter. It could've been a regular "entertain the player" scheme by making a fun little story, but as the game progresses the story proves to have a philosophical theme that exists in a larger world than just the fireplace. Accompanied with beautiful music, strongly cohesive design, and a though-provoking narrative, Little Inferno astounds the gamer who expects merely a little amusement from it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												From the makers of World of Goo comes Little Inferno.This game is strange, but that goes without saying, you buy items to burn in your fireplace, which give you more coins than you purchased them for to buy more items to burn. If the game had left it there I would have said don't bother with it but... there are combinations of things to burn. Like burning the Old lady and the kitty poo poo doll gives you the 'Cat Lady' combination. This gives you a stamp which, one you collect enough, allows you to buy another catalohue.Meanwhile while your burning things to yur hearts content theres a little plot going on through letters sent to you by your neighbour. I won't spoil anything but I didn't see it coming. Well the first bit I did, but not the second part.So yeah I recommend this, but only if its in a sale for maybe £3 or so., Its only a short game, you should be able to find most combinations in a very short time, and has little replay value since once you've burned everything and reached the end theres nothing much to do other than burn the same stuff again in a new game.

												Little Inferno is a hilarious game.So your parents are encouraging you to BURN all your toys in the fire place! You know, any parents would let their kid do that now a days, wouldn't they?If you have never seen a lets play/walk through/anything like that, I will tell you a little about it.You have to buy things from a catalog and make combos with the objects you buy. You can also do your own things and make funny combos(not even in the game) like using the dry ice to freeze stuff.You will not get any combo score for it, but you will get money for burning it/breaking it anyways!This game is hilarious, I could go on, but that is the basics of it.-I shot a piece of toast out of the toaster, froze it with dry ice, and made it my forever happy toast... XD-Rate: 11/10

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												Little Inferno is an unusual game to describe and ‘throwing your toys into the fire and playing with them as they burn’ doesn’t immediately sound as if it would make for an exciting experience. But with its satirical gameplay, gorgeous physics, grin-worthy humour, and positive message about not wasting your time on pointless things, here’s a title that adds up to more than the sum of its parts.Of course, it won’t be for everyone as it could be considered too ‘weird’ or ‘simplistic’. But look among the flames and you may just find a little game that burns brightly.A full review of Little Inferno can be found here:http://1001up.com/2015/11/05/review-little-inferno/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Ok, this game is a really odd one for me to recommend. It's a quirky puzzle game. You spend 95% of it buying items from a catalog and then buring said items in a furnace. While this may seem pointless at first glance it turns out that burning certain items along with certain other items at the same time will unlock "combos" which are basically the reason for the game. You are given a combo name and it's up to you to figure out what items are burnt to create that combo. The items all burn in different and often amusing/creepy ways. It's a bizarre little game with a disturbing theme and equally creepy story yet I found myself compelled to complete it. If you like trying to figure out combinations of items or just burning stuff (lol) then this game is for you!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												TL:DR Little Inferno is an indie game about burning catalog purchases to stay warm. Amusing burn animations, great indie graphics and subtle introspective social commentary critiquing the gaming industry and possibly world environment. Overall, good diversion, but sometimes painful delivery wait times. Suggested, but can benefit from DLC or updates.Now onto the full review, “Little Inferno” is an indie game available on PC, Mac, Android, IOS and probably your mom’s toaster. Created by Allan Blomquist, Kyle Gabler and Kyle Gray, presumably in their mom’s basement, advertises no outside funding or any other support in the creation of, “Little Inferno”.Marketed as 100% indie, DRM and IAP free, no form of copyright protection and spam and ad free, it currently goes for $10 dollars on the PC however, you can purchase it from Steam at $4.99 for the holidays.You enter the scene as a child, presumably abandoned by your parents for being a selfish git, and you’ve just received your, “Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace”. Encouraged to keep warm by purchasing and burning items found in catalogs, you progress through the game by spending money and stamps earned from burned items on new catalogs and bigger and better items. The gameplay is simple, you have no score, no time limits and the only goal is to burn stuff you buy from catalogs and everything else that comes into your possession including letters, and coupons for free hugs.During your pyro sessions, you’ll receive letters from three other characters, you’re neighbor that you’ve never seen, the company owner of your entertainment fireplace and the weather balloon guy that constantly lets you know that the weather shows no signs of improving.As you burn items, you’ll receive money and stamps. The money is needed to buy items and new catalogs, and the stamps are used to speed up the delivery of your catalog purchases.In order to buy the new catalogs, you’ll need to gain a certain number of combos. Combos are combinations of 2 or more items burned together.The game is very well situated to take advantage of touch screens, which is no surprise since the developers of, “Little Inferno” also developed, “World of Goo”, and there’s even a combo that pays homage to that game.Each item burned has a unique burn animation, and it’s important to remember what these are since the combo hints may reference this and you’ll end up having to repeat multiple burns to figure out what the hint is referencing.This may not be a bad thing since many of the burn animations are amusing enough to revisit multiple times, like screaming marshmallows and pixelated green fire.While the game is amusing enough to play through, I can’t help but think there’s a bit deeper meaning to the overall gameplay…something that overshadows the simple minded amusement.It seems there’s a bit of social commentary embedded in the game as well and it seems to present a situation where the, “Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace” can be equated to a gaming system like the PS4 or the Xbox. Ironically enough, the game appears to suggest that you step away from your system and explore the world.Through the progression of the game you’re in first person, fixated on the entertainment fireplace, and the only communication you have with anyone is through letters…which can be compared to text chat in MMO’s. You cannot turn away from the entertainment fireplace, and there is no mention of parents or siblings, adding to the self-imposed solitude of a gaming system.This notion is further enforced later in game through forced events and communication with other characters, and this game would not be the first game that encourages players to step away from the game and get out into the real world once in a while.I may be reading too much into this, but there seems to be additional commentary about the state of the world beyond the state of you as a gamer. You’re trapped in a world that is getting colder and being polluted from the smoke of your entertainment fireplace. Basically, the world’s environment is going to hell, and no one really cares as their too busy, “staying warm”. A letter from the weather balloon man enforces this idea.Both of these perceptions are strengthened by end game events which I won’t spoil for you and again, not sure if this was intended or not, but I’ll leave that conclusion up to you.The game, more than anything, a puzzle game, possibly a social commentary, and a relatively fun diversion from standard games that encourage e-peen waving. This is not, “Call of Duty”, or, “Assassin’s Creed”, nor does it intend to be.

												As I started playing it I quickly recognized the art and music styles to be almost identical to that of World of Goo, making me wonder if it was in fact the same dev team. It of course is not World of Goo, there's a story here and it's something far darker and more disturbing. I've barely started this game and I'm terrified of proceeding, dreading what horrible tragedy lurks in the next letter. Mechanically, the game is simple enough (it seems like it was designed for touchscreens.) Set stuff on fire, collect coins, buy more stuff to set on fire, burn different things at the same time to get combos.This game is not for everyone, but those people it IS for will love it to death.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												It's an interesting "interactive experience." Would I call it a game, per se? No. The graphics are charming and disturbing simultaneously, the fire effects look great, but at its core it's a condemnation of casual free-to-play mechanics, using same mechanics in a game you pay for. It's a condemnation of digital distribution services like Steam...on Steam. It's a game where the gameplay doesn't matter...then tells you it doesn't matter. If that sounds good to you, then get it. Personally, I would say it's not worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I wasn't going to recommend this game at first, but after playing it for several hours, I changed my mind.  After trying to figure out combos for more than four hours, this game grew on me.Summary of the game: Essentially, you spend the entire game throwing random objects in the fire.  Pretty simple.  As you play the game more and throw more into the fire, more items are unlocked.  If you run out of money to buy more objects, you can easily earn more money by waiting to burn spiders.  There are also list of combos you can earn by burning certain objects together.  Even though you spend 95% of the game burning objects, it still has an interesting storyline.First, reasons against recommending this game:1.) It's not worth $10.  It would be a stretch, but $5 might be ok.  2.) The scenery for the most part doesn't change.  You are in front of a fireplace for 95% of the game.3.) Some of the combos are too vague.  I feel like several of the objects not in the combo also fit the theme of the combo, and some of the combos are confusing.  There was one in particular that did not make any sense to me.  Some of the combos also need better hints.  I was able to complete all but 3-4 of them without help, and after getting help, I could tell that I wouldn't have figured them out on my own.Now, I'll go over why I like this game.  First of all, many of the combos are quite amusing and addicting (such as online piracy or LOL kitty).  Others are a fun challenge to figure out.  The selection of items to burn is amusing.  You can also choose to burn the photos from your own computer (all the photos have to be in your pictures folder though).  It comes in handy when you want to burn pictures of your ex, but you have no fireplace available for that purpose.  I got joy out of it even 1.5 years later.  The storyline is cute.  The ending is great!If you are a person that likes games with a ton of action and exciting adventures, this game is not for you.  However, if you like short, light games (especially ones that can distract you from schoolwork or chores), give this game a try!

Posted: May 24, 2014
												From the beginning when I watched the trailer/gameplay video I thought... what a weird simple (& probable short) game. Now after play 12+ hours I can say my first impression of the game was very wrong. Sure burning things and watch what they do when they are engolfed in fire is fun, but the core aspect of the game is making combo's. You need to try and match 1 item with another item soley based off the Combo's Name that is displayed in the combo list (some are 3 part combos). Some a very obvious and easy to figure out, and others can take a deep train of thought to figure out. Then meanwhile, there is also a letters being written to you by another character in the game that kinda creates a plot for the game. About the only negative thing I have to say about the game is the wait times on deliveries of your items you'll be burning. This aspect of the game just doesn't feel quite right. Why should I have to sit around and wait to play a game...  Besides that, a very enjoyable game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												World of Goo was unique, cheeky, seemed to look at the world in its own little way.  Little Inferno seeks to recapture that spirit and feel to solidify how 2D Boy games are like.  Unfortunately it just doesn't leave the same lasting impression.The game starts off innocently enough just like World of Goo does.  You have a fireplace and a cutesy, but loomingly sinister setting about snow that never stops falling and that you bought a fireplace to burn things in to stay warm.  You burn things, get money, and buy more things to burn.  These objects come in themes with increasingly tongue-in-cheek jabs at consumerism in general.  There is a surprising amount of little details in pretty much everything but at the same time, it really loses that luster and subtle humor after the first few times you burn something and it starts screaming.  However, as you keep playing, you realize about half-way through that this is all the game is and it quickly overstays its welcome.  Unlocking things is an incredibly lengthy process and finding all the various combos, that range from obvious to clever to straight up random, can sometimes be an exercise in straight guesswork.The visuals and sounds are highly reminiscent of World of Goo which from I figure seems to be the developers' attempt at a unique style which does suit the game rather well.  It's fairly easy to get absorbed in the atmosphere but it's also very easy to break said atmosphere.  The nods to World of Goo are ever present, but it almost feels like they draw too much from their past success to remind you how artsy and anti-establishment they are- almost to the point of tedium.The biggest problem with Little Inferno is that unlike World of Goo, you have to not only push yourself to finish it but there's absolutely no value in playing it more than once.  If you've done everything the first go around, the only thing you can do differently is not burn a single item you get early on that changes a single passing line of dialogue at the end.  It set itself up almost to feel like a spiritual successor to the beloved little puzzle game that I still highly recommend to anyone who would want to play it, but it wound up being too similar to World of Goo to stand out on its own, and too different from it to really hold my attention.It's been a while since I uninstalled and forgot about the game, and in hindsight, I kind of regret paying the full $15 for this one when it came out.  Fans of World of Goo or artsy indie stuff in general will still find something to enjoy from it, though.  It's not a bad game in its own right, but its lack of lasting presence really hurts it in the end.  You'll play it once and forget about it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I really love this game. At first you just have fun being a pyromaniac, burning all your toys so you can get more money and burn more toys. You can also create funny combos by burning certain things together. Then the story starts getting darker and more meaningful, and I found myself kept on asking questions about what am I doing in front of a fireplace and why am I here... One down side is this game does not have much replay value, unless you want to explore possible alternative endings, which may or may not exist in the first place. Overall, a very interesting game that would entertain you for a few hours, but leaves you thinking about you and the world for the rest of the day.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Maybe it's just a reflection of my age, but I found myself genuinely upset for having played this game all the way through.  What starts out as cutely creepy ends up being a soul sucking waste of time.  Too harsh?  I just feel like a game whose entire message is about going outside, talking to actual people, and not burning away one's time in front of some stupid distraction machine shouldn't then suck you in to do exactly that.  I don't know, maybe the developer wants you to feel awful by the time you've finished the game.  Like the cliche father sending his son out to the shed to smoke an entire pack of cigarettes as punishment for sneaking his first puff?  I agree with the message, and would much rather have a beer with friends than frag all day, but there are also those times when nothing else is going on, you're tired, and just want to chill out for a little fun escape...those times shouldn't be ruined by the guilt of Little Inferno.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												3 out of 5.I like Little Inferno. Unfortunately, I don't think it's worth the $10 it's going for. If you can find it for less than $5, grab it. Like other people have stated, this is mostly a chimney simulator. The goal of the game is to create combos of items that you obtain in the game and then burn them. Don't think that's it because these items just don't burn. They all do something special when that fire hits them and learning what they do when they burn is a big key to what items go with what in order to create the good combos. Now, the biggest gripe I've had with the game is that there IS a story in this game. The sad part is that we're hit with it too late and the interactions you have with the other characters is so small that the ending to this game makes you want more. The ending is great, but the story leading up to it is not in the same ball park. Take it for what it's worth, a pyromaniac's paradise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2013
												This is a very unique game that was a joy to play through. I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought it, but I do enjoy burning things so I went for it. What I found was a clever little game centered around burning things in a fireplace while receiving messages from the outside world. There is a steady progression as you burn things in combos to unlock more catalogues with more things to burn, and there is an engaging story happening at the same time via letters you receive. There are goals you can achieve such as unlocking all the combos, earning stars on all the catalogues and reaching the end of the story. However, I spent a lot of time just burning things. Most of the objects have animations that are activated when they are set on fire. Here's a tip - burn the edge of the object rather than just setting fire to the middle so you don't miss out on the clever animations. For example, there is a boat that will simply explode if you burn the middle. If you burn an outer edge, you get to watch it spurt oil and then fire before blowing up. The burning is great - oil paintings melt, fragile things are quickly reduced to ash, metal things leave charred skeletons. The only feature I would have liked to have seen would be a way to make up your own combos and share them with others. If you're looking for something different that you can enjoy at a leisurely pace, this game is an excellent choice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												The game is of a dystopian setting, where people don't tend to leave their homes, let alone their city. The weather has been getting worse, with snow constantly falling - was this intentional? The citizens spend their days ordering things from several catalogues so that they can burn them in the Little Inferno Fireplace to keep warm.You are a boy that is doing just that, and you get letters from several sources that progress the storyline. The more I play this, the more I am inclined to think that the constant snow is a corporate plan to keep everyone inside so that they can buy the Little Inferno Fireplace and the products in the catalogue?The game is graphically beautiful, and the way that you play it, as well as the story itself, it's just one of those games that you must play! It doesn't take that long to complete, if you know what to do!

												Simple game, but can become really boring. You buy and burn things in your fireplace. A lot of items have special effects or events that are triggered by setting them on fire. There is also a combo system, in which you combine items and burn them (you need to guess what should be used in a combo). Combos are listed and their titles can be helpful. There is also some kind of neighbour who sends you letters and items sometimes. She is a little girl and she wants to be your friend. You did not actually meet her. You also get some sort of weather news through letters. And that's it. The whole game. Burn everything and read letters.It is well made and it is enjoyable for couple of hours (or rather minutes), but it gets boring soon.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												After completing Little Inferno, it's a game that I would highly recommend for a tablet / mobile device, but struggle to recommend for PC. The biggest issue I had with the game was the time I spent doing other stuff. The basic mechanics of the main game are buying items from catalogs and burning them in the fireplace. The developers implemented a timed "shipping" mechanic, where once you buy an item, you must wait a certain period of time. In a way, I understand a bit what they were doing, but the last couple catalogs feature items with shipping times well into the 3-4 minute mark, and the final item takes a mind-numbing five minutes to ship. This is inexcusible for a PC game, waiting five minutes for no other reason than waiting. This absolutely drives pacing into the ground as you search for combos.     Speaking of combos, the combos fall into one of three catagories. There are some well thought out combos that, after about five minutes, you will figure out and maybe even smile at the logic. The vast majority of the combos are very easy to solve and you end up wating more for the item to show up than solving the puzzle. There are some combos that, unless you follow the same logic trail the developers did, you will need to look up. This happened about 3 or 4 times to me, with a couple combos I simply got lucky on guessing / happened to get while burning stuff for money.       This is a quite fun time waster, or if you are doing something else like playing a turn-based game online, but they ask 10 dollars, and there's no way I can recommend this as a full-fledged game. For a game this short and this expensive, there should be far less waiting around. Unless the game looks very interesting to you, wait for it to appear in a bundle or on sale and pick it up. I can recommend for 2-5 dollars, depending on interest level, but ten is just too much for a game this short and with this many delays.

												I played the whole game in one try, and enjoyed it a lot.  However, during the first minutes of gameplay of Little Inferno I wasn't feeling very comfortable with setting absolutely EVERYTHING on fire. Even school buses with kids screaming inside. It was funny how some things would react to the fire, but still, there seemed to be no purpose to it and I felt like only a psycho would enjoy it. But then an actual story started unveiling and hooked me... and the objects that you set on fire did the rest. As you advance the objects get sillier, and you can combine them with others to unlock even sillier combos. Without noticing it, you just keep on playing and playing until you reach the shocking ending.Recommended indeed.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												From the makers of World of Goo comes Little Inferno.This game is strange, but that goes without saying, you buy items to burn in your fireplace, which give you more coins than you purchased them for to buy more items to burn. If the game had left it there I would have said don't bother with it but... there are combinations of things to burn. Like burning the Old lady and the kitty poo poo doll gives you the 'Cat Lady' combination. This gives you a stamp which, one you collect enough, allows you to buy another catalohue.Meanwhile while your burning things to yur hearts content theres a little plot going on through letters sent to you by your neighbour. I won't spoil anything but I didn't see it coming. Well the first bit I did, but not the second part.So yeah I recommend this, but only if its in a sale for maybe £3 or so., Its only a short game, you should be able to find most combinations in a very short time, and has little replay value since once you've burned everything and reached the end theres nothing much to do other than burn the same stuff again in a new game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I didn't really know what to expect from this game going in. I picked it up in a humble bundle and it sat untouched in my library for a while. Then one day I just felt like burning something. Well, good news if that sounds like fun to you. That is all you do in this game, burn stuff in a little fireplace, and then you buy more stuff and then you burn it. To some this may sound dull, so let me explain, there is a story taking place, and there is an "ending." There are achievments and combos to make, and the animations are very tim burton-esque. I enjoyed the sheer dark humor of the story put in front of me, while I mindlessly ignored all the games warnings and burned my fireplace's manual. This is the mindset you put yourself in while playing. You can easily "burn" this one out in an afternoon (LOL bad pun I know.) but certainly worth the money. You'll enjoy it, I know you are all pyros anyways.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2013
												This game takes a dark twist of the usually fun and satisfying activity of setting fire to various objects that you own(ed).The world is getting colder, it's the opposite scenario of what is happening in real life, and you're not allowed to go outside. You have no gas or electricity, so there's only one thing you can do to stop freezing; You have to burn things. Lots of things. More things than you have ever burnt in real life, and ever will, unless you do this for living, of course.You find a letter, several letters infact. Terms and conditions - burn. Greetings from producer - burn. Envelope from secret lover? - burn. You burn things if you didn't already get the memo.I would rate this game a 7/10. It's a nice game, could be a bit cheaper, and really, it's basically just about teaching you a life lesson which I refuse to spoil in this review.

												A charming little game that you can expect to spend a few hours in. There's a sweet story amongst all the fun of watching things incinerate or blow up, and combo hunting will keep you busy.
